2qT1VnsikZpEm2ytdHO9Ow.text: I've been a fan of Ottolenghi and his establishments for over 2 years.  In 2011 I ate at NOPI and on planning our trip this year made sure to get reservations far in advance.  NOPI emphasizes the flavors and tastes of food esp vegetables, but this is not a vegetarian restaurant.  The menu changes often to reflect Ottolenghi's taste and we were not disapointed.  Last time we sat in the main dining room and had a very sedate and pleasant experience.  But when I went downstairs to the restroom, I found a different experience for those diners.  There are 2 large tables that each sit 18 people and these tables face the open kitchen.Needless to say, this time I wanted to sit downstairs and was rewarded by excellent service and the ambiance of seeing the meals prepared.  It elevated my dining experience and my wife and I had a fabulous time.  We ordered 6 small plates and two desserts.  We chose different glasses of wine for the courses. Our server Alain was attentive but non-intrusive.If you love vegetables, are willing to taste the innovative use of spices and small plates to share, then head to NOPI; if you're a meat and potatoes kind of person and the only vegetable you commonly see is parsley, then head somewhere else.

HHIHbKu5ZIMTd8jHUPJmsQ.text: During our trip to London in January 2013 we had Sunday lunch in Nopi. Last time we were in London we ate in Ottolenghi's in Islington - this new location didn't disappoint at all.The decor is white and gold, yet manages not to look either too brashy or too sterile; quite a trick when the whole restaurant is white glazed tiles.We love Ottolenghi's food, so we knew we were in for a treat, but even-so the Shakshuka was an absolute delight; the best of eggs, so many subtle flavours and spices, and the creamy-yet-subtle smoked labneh... anticipation turned to contented bliss as I tasted the first bite - a real experience.Nopi also feature a bar, and we had to try it out! 2 non-alcoholic cocktails and a good long chat with the bar manager and also the restaurant manager Basia; the passion that all the staff have for food is very apparent.Next time we're in London, Nopi is number-one on our list to return to; a new favourite.

9FHfj9sMXjPycau9g_UPng.text: I've had Nopi on my list of places since it's another Ottolenghi restaurant..The menu is starter size portions, similar to the evening menu at Ottolenghi. I think the highlight for me is the vegetable dishes (as is the case at Ottolenghi). Delicious courgette fritters, excellent green beans with Chinese mushrooms and some grains, really special roasted aubergine with pickled cucumber and pumpkin seeds. We also sampled smoked eel, baby chicken with lemon myrtle salt and pork belly.  All were great with interesting taste and texture combinations with the exception of the pork belly which surprisingly was tough and plain in taste and we didn't finish. Kale and rainbow chard on the side was OK with garlic and vinegary dressing but not too exciting.Cocktails were good with some interesting ideas and just the right level of sour / bitter and importantly not sweet.The staff were wonderful, friendly, welcoming and attentive with good timing on the food and the atmosphere was just right. Slight buzz, chatty but amazingly not too loud at all given the reflective white tiled walls.Overall a great meal with one or two minor dips in greatness. The restaurant and staff were perfect but the food overall was not quite as special as Ottolenghi in Islington, in my humble opinion which surprised me but then maybe the slightly higher prices here and expectations were set too high so 4 stars overall.

jaNnmPs6BLmPjzcRSsMCOQ.text: I was expecting not to like NOPI, but I was so pleasantly surprised. EVERYTHING we ate was absolutely delicious- the chicken and seared tuna were both delicious. The zucchini fritters are a must try. If you like eggplant, that was wonderful as well. The decor is nothing special, but it is light and airy and a great place to catch up with friends. Service was on point. I will be returning.

Whn7vMtd-lwA4wql9OIyfQ.text: I had a chance to have lunch at Nopi on a recent trip to London, and sat in the more informal downstairs part of the restaurant.  The downstairs communal seating was cozy, with a fun view into the kitchen.  The food itself was delicious - the ingredients were all fresh and seasonal, with inventive presentations.  The only downside for me was the service; for the amount you pay, I would have expected it to be excellent, but I didn't find the staff to be particularly friendly or attentive.

GQTiIffNw2PnQafslFzYTQ.text: Nice. I liked it. I sat at the bar for lunch (originally had a table booked downstairs, but there was no one else there) and ended up next to a nice couple. I had a glass of wine, butternut squash & octopus, finished off with an espresso. I eat a good amount, but didn't even touch the bread (which is baked at their own bakery), because the 2 to-share dishes were enough for me. Service was great, and food was delicious. Worth every penny.

Ea9MN7dNl5qfb7SuyMYj9Q.text: Upscale Mediterranean FareVisit: October 8Prior to visiting London, I asked my friends for recommendations for eating in London and I got a very dismal response. Basically I was told that the fare in London was not good. Well phooey. London is a world-renowned city with a very diverse and demanding cultural scene so I knew there was good food to be had. Thanks to Yelp and all the Yelpers who contribute reviews, I found this restaurant. My husband and I enjoyed our best dinner at Nopi during our week visit to London. First of all, I was impressed with the décor. This space was obviously remodeled and felt very new. The color scheme is white...white walls, white table clothes, white marble floors. The marble had golden veins throughout, the gold coat hangers attached to the walls, and the brushed gold low-lit lanterns gave the room a nice warm glow. The only color came from a very incongruous painting on the back wall. In my amateur interior decorating opinion, the painting did not go with the theme or ambiance of the restaurant. The wait staff was dressed in severe black with white aprons and the room got its vibrancy from the patrons and the inventive cuisine that was served.My husband and I started with a sparkling wine: a Spanish rose (Cuvée rosé 'Jeio', Bisol) for me and an Italian sparkler (Prosecco "Garbel", Adami) for Andy. We were both pleased with the wine. While we were enjoying our apéritif, we sampled the brown bread with olive oil. The olive oil was divine. It was obvious the oil was very fresh due to its very aromatic scent and wonderfully flavorful taste. The brown bread had a nice crust and a soft, light center that easily soaked up the delicious olive oil. We ordered 2 tapas and they arrived very quickly. The individual components of the roasted red pepper ensemble melded together delightfully and the sprinkle of the sharp and tangy goat cheese added a nice bite to the sweet and savory peppers. We never had burrata but we like mozzarella and several reviews highly recommended this Italian artisanal cheese so we decided to try it. Burrata is fresh mozzarella blended with cream giving the cheese enhanced creaminess and an airy, fluffy texture. It had little flavor but it paired extremely well with the slices of nectarine and the coriander seeds. Both of our sparkling wines accentuated the 2 tapas.We selected 2 more items for dinner: the mackerel and the rotolo, which we asked our waiter what rotolo was. He described it like a cannelloni. The rotolo was filled with spinach, butternut squash, and smoked ricotta surrounded with a pecan pesto. I thought the smoked ricotta was too smoky and overpowered the rest of the flavors but my husband really enjoyed it. The filet of mackerel was pan seared accompanied with a creamy sauce and a grape salsa topped with tobiko. The fish was tender and flakey with a light saltiness. The combination of the savory sauce and the subtly sweet grapes was unexpected and delicious. Andy ordered a glass of a French rosé (Château La Coste, Côtes du Provence) and I picked out a white wine from France but our waiter said that was a bad choice. It's a good thing I'm not a wine snob or I would have taken offense but instead I asked him what he recommended to pair with the mackerel. He suggested a Gruner Veltliner (Huber, "Ober Steigen", Weingut). The bright and acidic Gruner paired exceptionally well with the mackerel and the creamy sauce.We received efficient service and the meal was well orchestrated at a leisurely pace. There were many vegetarian options and I liked the heartiness and creativity of the menu. The chef definitely put his own signature on the Mediterranean dishes. Overall: great wine, great food, and great service!

4M0NpoccaWI8xFf7D54IIQ.text: The pairings at Nopi are truly divine. burrata rata with nectarine and coriander. aubergine with pomegranate and feta. duck breast with watermelon and grilled shrimp. the list continues. my stomach grows bigger. The ambience is exactly how I want to furnish my home. Lovely white palette with a minimalistic sense, yet key pieces that provide warm hues (lemons, lemon painting, soft wood candle holders..). The devil is in the detail.

kQnQhDZU8iJu_QvuLus91g.text: Yeah, I'm going to go there: I'm saying nope-y to NOPI.The tragic part is that it isn't the food that was a let-down, it was absolutely the staff. If you happen to follow my reviews, you'll know that I'm practically willing to permit bodily harm so long as the meal itself shines, but man, I have limits, too.Allow me to set the scene: three friends getting together for a Sunday brunch on a nice, late-summer day. We were the third table seated (I was a bit naive to think I needed reservations at that hour, fair enough) at 10:30am. We weren't allowed to choose a nicer table despite there being not a soul on that end of the restaurant, but alright, let's pretend everyone else got reservations, too.Menu? Very limited (we knew it'd be) but promising, with nice twists and classics side by side. The other gals went for breakfast sandwiches, I went for the shakshuka because friends, I cannot say no to shakshuka. It might be chronic at this point.Our tea arrived, we chatted, a couple more tables got seated.And we waited.Then we waited.We ordered more tea (three attempts at flagging down two separate servers before we succeeded), and 50min after sitting down, our food arrived, with only a slight delay between the sandwiches (which arrived first) and my eggs-in-tomato sauce dish, with no apology or acknowledgement from the server that it might be a little slow in coming. We joked lightly about how, you know, they'd clearly been curing the bacon and smoking my labneh back there all that time, but the food was quite nice. I can't say the bite I had of the breakfast sandwich was particularly earth-shattering, but it was certainly a nice interpretation of heart attack in a bun. I was a little disappointed with my shakshuka. I expected spice, and quite a bit of it, and got none. There were enough herbs and seasoning to keep it from being bland, but I kept hoping that I'd poke my way under a bit of tomato to uncover some heat. Alas.We decided to aim for gluttony and get pancakes to share three ways because YOLO at NOPI. (I'm sorry, I don't understand why the restaurant name is yelling at me.) It took about 10min to flag anyone down, we sipped our tea and... you guessed it. We waited. And waited.40min after ordering, the pancakes arrived. And hey, they were really tasty. At this point, the restaurant was getting more full and we were getting a little antsy; there's a point at which brunch becomes lunch, and we were starting to encroach on that.Then came the really fun part: trying to get our check.It took three servers and four attempts before we actually received it. We then couldn't find anyone to actually come by to take our money.When we were finally able to leave, we had been there just under three hours.Let that sink in.3 hours for two breakfast sandwiches, six cups of tea, and a stack of pancakes. In that time, I don't think I saw a single server make a welcoming, friendly, or warm facial expression.At the very least, you would think that the staff would want to turn over the tables more quickly to keep customers flowing, but apparently they're more interested in actively ignoring any and every polite attempt to make eye contact or establish a line of communication.Was the food good? Yes. Was it great? No. Is it worth going back? I wouldn't.

mcsSuymYURV0kNIPc3dN4A.text: party of 3 with drinks 2 appetizers and mains for £130.  a bit of an expensive fare but good nonetheless.- courgette fritters - come in 3s and the cardamom is overpowering. different from your usual fritters- sweet potato wedges - nicely charred with an aubergine dip and sprinkled with pomegranate seeds- barley risotto with mushrooms; rottolos with ricotta; and the seared tuna with greens.We had 3 drinks - one bourbon and raspberry cocktail, one mocktail and a fizzy cocktail.very tasty and very nice vibe in the restaurant.Service was a-ok... the waiters felt a bit stuck up and did not mind interrupting our conversation or not showing much care when removing plates from the table.The bathrooms to be mentioned.  Very nice and clean and wall-to-wall mirrors. Located downstairs where the communal tables are.  will probably not be back unless someone else is footing the bill.

SDiT7SEkKzDCts22jOr27Q.text: Weird food, little portions, not really any meats to speak of. Probably a good place if you are a vegetarian.The bartender was the best part of the meal.They serve Cheesecake that is hot and has no cream cheese in it. It's odd.It's also very expensive, the food is served like tapas at 8-12 quid each. Be aware of that. This will be a 80-100 quid meal with drinks for 2.

kutja_4HViu9whPs16eY1Q.text: Outstanding!Very good service, lively but not overwhelming atmosphere, and best of all the food is absolutely stunning. We had a sort of a tapas of smaller vegetarian dishes and all of them were beautifully prepared and tasted superb. We both agreed the Beetroot and Valdeon cheesecake was our favourite, bit only just. Thank-you so much for a wonderful birthday lunch

Kk1tyZenQPQ3htwu4f9Uhg.text: I'm in love. The dishes were amazing. So cool being downstairs watching the chefs prepare everything and work as a team. Lovely experience. The waitress came over to explain "how it all works"--it's a dining experience more than just a meal. We did the sharing option--so lots of little dishes so we could sample a lot. RESERVE!!!!

EbWLipty1srH_M146vmilg.text: My expectations were maybe to high. I loved the atmosphere, but was just ok with the food. I found the flavors to be ok. There isn't a dish that I would rave about that we ordered. And since we shared everything we ordered I tried a bit of almost everything. I think it's a Gelina, Venice Beach wanna-be.

3lxwx36b2eoBfL6NWiLimw.text: We had a very long "wet lunch" at NOPI and left very happy, to say the least. It is an outstanding restaurant in Soho with a beautiful light-filled interior, fabulous food and service! We will be returning the next time we are in London. Basia Murphy made our experience unforgettable. The dishes we tried were sharing plates, including the burrata with peaches, fennel and coriander seeds, courgette and manouri fritters, cardamom yoghurt, pork belly, black bean ragù, yuzu puré, crushed beetroot, grains of paradise labneh, walnuts, valdeón cheesecake, pickled beetroot, hazelnut, thyme honey, seared scallops, sea spaghetti, shiitake, all washed down with several bottles of a 1er Cru Meursault (let's just say we left the restaurant feeling pretty good). Each dish was fresh and elegant, a fusion of Middle Eastern, Mediterranean and Asian flavours. If you are a fan of Yotam Ottelenghi, you will love his restaurant NOPI. We also left with his cookbook "Jerusalem", which he signed for us.I highly recommend you dine in this gorgeous restaurant!

WbKHrNzs_IKs1NqSOsvPHw.text: Absolutely fantastic!Went for a Sunday lunch (make sure to book a week in advance) and it was one of the best lunch I have ever had.Great service, patient  waiterUnique combination of food: innovative Middle Eastern yet modernIf you want to enjoy as many plates as possible, I recommend ordering many "dishes to share". For the two of us we had:- Hummus (comes with little seeded crackers)- Roasted sweet potato, burnt aubergine yoghurt, basil, maple roasted seeds- Roasted aubergine, lemon chilli feta,pistachios-Venison, caramelised yoghurt, blackberries, peanut crumble- Lamb sweetbreads, wasabi peas, miso-Truffled polenta chips, spicy tomato chutney- Cardamon rice pudding, rose syrup, pistachio.We shared everything and it was the perfect meal. Was not in a food coma after, yet I had the feeling that I had eaten a satisfying lunch.  All of this for a total of =£65! not bad at all for a fine restaurant like Nopi.In a nutshell: cannot wait to try breakfast now and go to other of Ottolenghi's locations!

UnVJV0yYpyhEWZUjoafbKA.text: Excellent food.  Excellent & friendly service.  Expensive.  You'd struggle to spend less than £35 per person.Only 1 vegetarian main course option on the menu when I went.

mxteK6_8cSl42-mnbFYDGQ.text: I love love love this place. I drag anyone and everyone here when I am in London. On my last solo trip, I ate here twice. Small plates are good to share, but most of it is so good, you really shouldn't feel like sharing. Tell your bestie to get their own food.  I have yet to dine downstairs, but the upstairs can vary in noise level from busy to chaotic and frenzied, so avoid Friday Christmas lunches if you are any way sensitive.The drinks are amazing, if not a little over iced.  The bathroom is also work a look, probably before your second drink. Brunch/Breakfast is definitely worth enjoying - the coconut rice and the shakshusha are fabulous.  Ottolenghi sources fancy eggs from Italy - the yolks are quite orange. A bit lurid, but delicious.  Breakfast, lunch, dinner, you cannot go wrong.

eOJHaHhsJqiKWcFa52AaxQ.text: We had our diner downstairs next to the kitchen. The starters were great and then a main course with duck. Absolutely top!! Very enjoyable evening. Must visit again

RXSuMHPwi9iv84P2n_VOfg.text: This restaurant is amazing! Essentially, Israeli tapas with flavors I have rarely tasted anywhere else. The staff is super friendly and the bar staff are very talented. I am dying to go back!

YUrsdvLEzZDGXV8FjEv9Dg.text: What can I say about NOPI? It's simply put, one of the best meals I've had in my entire life.A few weeks before coming to spend a few days in London, my party of four booked reservations  to sit in the communal downstairs section of the restaurant. We planned our day for sight-seeing out to make sure we were a short walk away in time for our reservation. An easy walk 15 minute walk from Buckingham Palace, we were greeted at the restaurant by a friendly and pleasant staff. We sat at the end of a long table that can seat about 14-16 people. The table was quite tall and I usually find these uncomfortable, as tall chairs cut off circulation in my short chubby legs; however, these seats were perfectly comfortable. Our table neighbors were all friendly but respected that we were a group of friends having dinner together and kept conversation with us to a few polite interactions.I started my meal with a cocktail that was amazingly delicious: a Rooibos Old Fashion. Made with Fernet Branca and chocolate bitters, the bourbon and rooibos tea syrup blend so well that I could have had four of five of them and skipped dinner altogether. Everyone else also seemed to enjoy their cocktails that night: one had a Ginseng & Grapefruit, another a Banana & Cardamom, and lastly, a Raspberry & Bourbon. All were a hit!We decided to have our dinner "tapas" small plate style and split everything between us. We shared Jicama & salsa, vegetable crudités, olives, burrata & blood orange salad, beetroot & goat's curd salad, cheese w/ peaches, and a Kale, Apple, and Turnip salad.When I say that all of these were amazing... my words do not do them justice. All were a revelation of how good properly prepared vegetables can be. Everyone agreed that we could have had a purely vegetarian meal and walked out delighted. My personal favorite was the beetroot and goat's curd salad - which I declared would be the last thing I tasted with the meal before dessert.We also ordered two mains to split between the four of us: the seared tuna and the rotolo. Both were phenomenal. The tuna was cooked perfectly and prepared in such a way that if you were to close your eyes you would believe you were eating a delicate cut of beef. The rotolo, made with spinach, mushrooms, and a walnut miso, was also just incredible. We all agreed that the mains would have been wonderful meals to have alone if we weren't in a sharing mood.Lastly, dessert (aka puddings) - We ordered three for us to share: I had chocolate with orange oil and crème fraîche... it was chocolate heaven with a sultry richness that should be illegal. We also ordered an apple gingerbread trifle with celery sorbet... I didn't try any because I was in a chocolate nirvana but more than one person raved over the celery sorbet. We also had a tau fu fa (a type of tofu pudding) that was also delicious!This was easily the best meal I've had in London and one of the best in my life. You can bet that whenever I am in London, I'll make sure I have a reservation for the downstairs at NOPI.

photos.caption: Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Downstairs table

aJehEwYpRZk0EbSvU-pw5w.text: I was expecting something amazing when I saw such great reviews everywhere and ended up being a bit disappointed.You absolutely have to book in advance and I would recommend staying upstairs as there is absolutely no day light otherwise. It is this new kind of restaurant in London where you get a lot of small portions and share. The food is good, but all the meals we had (6people sharing, firsts, mains and sides) were missing that little something to be very good. Really nothing that would bring me back there.The coconut icecream at the end had too much lemon grass (not written on the menu) and tasted like soap. That was quite bad. Definitely not worth the price, that's for sure.

1wakdYOA0_9P4CBlRcv8uw.text: NOPI was a great dining and social experience. There were six of us, and the restaurant came highly recommended. For the most part, it did not disappoint. The menu was varied and fun, but overpriced. My "twice cooked half chicken, lemon myrtle salt, chili sauce" cost 22 Pounds; last night's feast at grungy chain restaurant Nando's of "half chicken with Peri-Peri sauce" was better, at 7 Pounds. Fancy chef, fancy prices. Nonetheless, NOPI offered two amazing things: bathrooms that were floor-to-ceiling mirrors straight out of the 70's, and a wonderful sensitivity to food allergies on behalf of one of our friends. In fact, our server was given a list of said allergies and soon returned with an updated menu that crossed out all dishes that contained the harmful ingredients. This level of service was indicative of the evening, including gentle reminders that our allotted dining time was ending in 18 minutes. We ignored them and ordered dessert instead. All in all, a fun spot worth a try.

WbmGdVSnEkvDIZHx-EJlOg.text: Gorgeous decor with a classy and relaxed feel. Bookings are a must and even with a booking I believe we still waited almost 10 minutes for a table to be ready. We opted for a variety of small plates and enjoyed them all. Normally, when ordering a variety of small plates the waiter asks how you would like the plates timing wise. Or they just evenly space it out with the heavier courses closer to the end.Unfortunately, we received all of our dishes at once which was a visual delight but was not optimal. Unless you want to inhale your food, the dishes get a bit cold as you nibble through. The twice cooked chicken was moist and flavourful with a lovely crisp skin. The courgette fritters were fragrant with herbs but but were a tad soggy. Polenta chips = yum, fluffy pillows fried to a crisp.

sZyZ5lccHItGpJ2D42gb7Q.text: One word. AMAZING! We had 5 of the 'tapas' style dishes. With each one we had to stop talking and enjoy the flavours and textures so beautifully blending in our mouths. For the quality and service I was expecting a much bigger bill. Great experience all around.

C11sK3CEiaChwJtkzsP5dw.text: I am a massive Ottolenghi fan, and had wanted to eat at Nopi for years, so when I was in London in december 2014, I seized the chance.We started our meal with some delicious cocktails - mine had champagne, elderflower gin and saffron liqueur. We were advised to order 2-3 sharing plates each. We started off with courgette fritters with cardamom yoghurt, which were a stroke of culinary genious, grilled aubergine with lemon, nuts and pickled cucumber (equally delicious), and burrata with clementine and coriander seeds (another fantastic combination). We then had cod with pistachios and butter, which was cooked to perfection, and the twice-cooked chicken which was served with a spiced salt and hot sauce - seriously yummy!Although we were by this time exceedingly full, we just  could not pass on the tempting desserts on offer. We went for the peanut ice cream with chocolate sauce, and the chocolate ganache with creme fraiche and orange oil. Both were scrumptious, and the chocolate with orange oil was particularly inspiring.Alltogether, Nopi livded up to my high expectations, and I would definitely go again when opportunity presents itself!

luCe5RAYzq3I6NakPeF6ng.text: I loved this restaurant so much! I want to go back! Sadly, I live three thousand miles away, so I'll have to settle for the cookbook.The service was impeccable, the decor was tasteful, and the was food delicious.My family and I shared a number of vegetarian dishes: the burrata with blood orange, the butternut squash, which was perfectly accented by the tart lime yoghurt, the courgette and manouri fritters. I loved the chickpea pancake, which was spicy and crisp.My meat-eating family also enjoyed the duck and the scallops.We shared two puddings. I am a true chocolate lover, and the I thought the baked ganache was good. The subtle addition of popping candy ("Pop Rocks" in the states, although I don't know whether this candy has a different name in the UK) was an interesting touch. However, the peanut butter and caramel ice cream with chocolate sauce and peanut brittle was definitely the star of the show, with the perfect combination of salty and sweet, creamy and crunchy.

Cnn6AUekb7kEa6O3jP_tuQ.text: Coming in blind here but I don't get why this place is so highly rated. Cocktails were decent but food was nast.

P5MX-QjOnCGKSQUIra6DEA.text: Allthough it's pretty close to Picadilly circus it's located in a rather quite street. Guests are more locals than tourists. Guys behind the bar are handsome, friendly and professional.The food is excellent, very special combination of tastes. They could allow more time between courses, it is all served a bit too fast and I get the feeling that I have to make place for others. My last small complaint would be that the dishes should be a bit warmer... but apart from that: an excellent experience... thank you

photos.caption: Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Excellent Amaretto sour with egg white, the best Amaretto sour in a while!
Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Tea-smoked lamb cutlet wit jalapeno salsa and miso aubergine, brown lentil, cumin and crispy shallots

BxaEDf7fa2vXmEDSGhSoVg.text: It's great for vegetarians! I've been here twice, once for brunch and dinner. Both menus were amazing, he's also my favorite chef.I've cooked from his cookbooks, I'd say the recipes are better in there. I'm assuming he's catering to all palettes, so the taste in simpler but he gets points for freshness.

h2H1DdGtcdX6QKY-5jnUaw.text: I mean, so flipping on point.  Everything.  Like, literally EVERYTHING.I had been to Ottolenghi before, so was already well-primed to love up on NOPI.  "Do you know why it's called NOPI?" asked our super-invested server"Ermmm...""Think of the location""[channelling NYC-isms] North of...Picadilly".  Yep.  Ok, so that out of the way:I was dinner-ing with my veggie friend, so we went whole hog (sorry; inappropriate wordplay?) on...vegetables only.  We're talking AMAZING seeded flatbread with a burnt spring onion dip.  The *most delicious* eggplant with black garlic and basil.  Sweet potato with burnt aubergine yogurt and pomegranate seeds.  Charred broccoli with cucumber.  Slightly slimy okra with Asian flavours.  Courgette fritters with cardamom yogurt.HECK YEAH to all of those things.The cocktails were also marvellous.  Lemon-infused vodka, and grapefruit bitters and Hendrick's punch and saffron syrups and liqueurs and raspberry jam I'd never heard off (note: not all together; we had multiple rounds).All in we left feeling deliciously satisfied.  50GBP/head isn't an everyday meal, but will be one I remember for a long time.Yelp note: sitting at individual tables is possible, but we really enjoyed the large marble communal tables in the basement.  Double hint - use the bathrooms - they are trippy/great/trippy (especially after a few)!

Blc6CqpHtcoEn2IXIKzlbQ.text: This is a fabulous restaurant! 100% recommend! All our food was delicious, our cocktails and wines were beautiful and the service was fantastic. A must for all foodies.

NsJrj3zJhBfuROvmgQCfdA.text: I need to go back, or maybe I need to reset my taste buds. Honestly, I am so disappointed at me as I can hardly recall anything special from this place. I have been to Ottolenghi and liked it so what is the deal? We shared a bunch of stuff, and the only stuff I recall tasty, and made me think "wait this is something unique" is the pork belly and a malt flavored ice cream for desert. We had the burrata, the sweet potatoes, the courgettes fried, the backed beans, the chicken, ... and nope nothing made me raise an eyebrow. I think I did not pick the right stuff. Big plus though: the place is super nice, especially the chef's table downstairs where we sat. Lights are perfect. Staff is nice, and this place has a real overall nice feel. The exact same feeling I had at Ottolenghi. So well, yes I need to check NOpi again.

Tz4Sn-4ZmH-XImO7gAcZwg.text: An oasis of warmth and originality in Soho, Nopi is a classy, professional and adventurous restaurant.Despite my reservation not being in the system (possibly an open table issue), the host took it in his stride and found a table for me without an issue.Being led through the restaurant, the unique decor of all white tiles and brick, dimly lit through copper uplight fixtures, presented a mood one could describe as a sexy, sultry underground subway - if such a thing were to exist. Alas, on the music front, they went for boppy background shit when they could have completed the picture with some gritty blues/jazz reminiscent of an old blind African American busking guitarist in that same subway.  If not, the restaurant could have at least chosen something more original than dated Cafe Del Mar shit.I went for their spin on an old fashioned with Rooibos tea and chocolate bitters which was brilliant. The wine selection was equally brilliant - with some adventurous departures like a Sicilian Catarratto which is pretty unique (salty white wine!)... The Italian barbera (bandita cascina tavijn) was also pretty damn good, albeit traditional.Food wise, the cougette fritters were good, but nothing to write home about. The mullet I had to try, because as my father says - "you can't make strawberry jam from pig shit", but they managed admirably through a creative Indian stock with potatoes and mustard. The pork belly was an absolute standout - sweet pumpkin and a walnut Apple salsa worked perfectly!Staff were attentive and engaged, speed - a little rushed but not excessively and noise a nice balance of bustle with intimacy..Overall 4 stars - worth a visit and actually better value than I was expecting...Stop press... As I finish this review at their bar area (perfect for single diners) I am having a final cocktail - a Chilli Old Fashioned with Anejo, bloody delicious to finish!!!!I hope this helps your visit. Enjoy!

cemZv7nl8fFVi8eu69lq_w.text: One of the best meals of my life. Maybe even THE best. I was actually trying to make a reservation at a sister restaurant, Ottolenghi, and I was probably drinking too much wine or something and accidentally booked a table at NOPI instead. Happiest accident ever.About that reservation -- you'll want to make one -- especially if you're not from London and want to guarantee your seat. The upstairs is a bit more formal, and the downstairs is more casual, communal seating. And since I'm usually a hot mess when I'm traveling (or just in general), I decided the dark and cozy downstairs was right for me.No matter which part of the restaurant you're in, it's all beautiful. I love spots that are both upscale and casual at the same time. Everything was pristine, but nothing was fussy.Everyone at NOPI was incredibly friendly and genuinely helpful. Our server for the evening was a lovely young woman with a tight blonde pony and the sweetest disposition. She was subtly funny, and she took great care of us all evening. I never wanted for a thing. I have this wheat thing, and NOPI was stellar with helping me navigate around it. There were no questions or doubts -- only delicious food. In fact, NOPI is pretty darn spectacular with any type of allergy or dietary restriction. Almost everything our table ordered was vegetarian and gluten-free.For the full description of our dinner, check out Keith M's review. Since he went into so much detail, I'll skip that part. But I will tell you that I've never seen ingredients layered so well as NOPI did it. It's weird -- there were all these single items that I normally don't care for, but when combined with others, everything was absolutely perfect. For example, I don't care for fennel, but this warm peach, fennel, and soft cheese dish made even that vile weed taste delicious! Do yourself a favor and don't question or try to change anything -- just order it, and I promise you'll be a happy camper. If you're in (or headed to) London, NOPI should be at the top of your list!Pro tip: The owner and chef writes amazing cookbooks, and autographed copies are available at the front desk!

MwfCPOeBQY-4g1ufZrwdcg.text: A favourite for a quality breakfast. I always go for the shakshuka or the french toast. You can't find better around there!

photos.caption: Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Shakshuka

twDlE8IOBtHAFLchO0WGEQ.text: Popped in here randomly one weeknight with no rez. Posh place but figured, what the heck, lemme try. The hostess said I could sit at the bar but had to leave in an hour and a half for another rez. Totally doable. The barstaff was on target, friendly and attentive to my food questions and requests- VERY unusual in Europe but also much appreciated for how much you are paying for the price here. I got the roasted aubergine w/ pecans, goat cheese and pomegranate seeds and roasted butternut squash with cardamom yoghurt, pumpkin seeds. My gosh, I dropped my fork for each first bite of each plate bc it was that delicious. I haven't had food this good since NYC. The rich flavors, texture and creamy natures all blended incredibly well. I left spending a small fortune but incredibly mouth-happy. Just a little sad that one has to pay that much in London to get food that good, when amazing food can be had in NYC for half the price.

PX5mCwfqgUAM6s4Neb_Dqw.text: I don't understand the hype about this place. The chef is talented, his cookbooks are great and beautiful but doesn't carryover or executed well by his Chef @ Nopi. Limited menu however inventive ingredients which initially sound great. Server recommended 6-8 small dishes to share. We followed this rec however felt the dishes didn't agree with each other and competing spices (cayenne- lemon- coriander- bitter) just didn't work across. Overpowering seasoning in the aubergine mixed with an spiked lemon left a bitter taste for the meal. Crudités with avocado dip was simply garden carrots and radishes on a plate with mashed, spicey avocado. Burrata presented as a white ball with a drizzle of green sauce. It was ok. Nothing special. Scallops were highlight being super fresh. I wouldn't necessarily recommend this restaurant as I feel it's all hype and nothing special. Very lackluster. Actually 1st time I left a restaurant still being hungry. Overpriced too.

KQMCYTbVN6jvAfPvGceM2A.text: Excellent food. I ordered a bunch of vegetarian dishes and was pleasantly surprised at the attention to detail in how they were prepared. Flavorful. Courgette and Manouri fritters are highly recommended.You must reserve in advance. I had to change them a couple of times and they were most accommodating.

8lZDGfbE_Gv9Po1cP803QA.text: This place feels rather grown up - golden napkin holders, sophisticated clientele, a respectable address and an interesting menu. Was here for a brunch with the girls and was pleasantly surprised by the reasonably priced and interesting fare. It felt relatively approachable for an iconic name backing it - Ottolenghi. The shakshuka (braised eggs, piquante tomato sauce, smoked labneh) was divine. I was pregnant at the time of my visit and instructed the staff to ensure the eggs were fully cooked so I wasn't thrilled that I had to send it back to the kitchen to solidify the runny bits... but the quality of the food and the delightful flavours more than made up for the inconvenience! The carrot, ginger and apple juice made for a great accompaniment as well.

HNP1H0CMzH94AfEpog0IDA.text: We were wandering aimlessly around Soho looking for a dinner spot when we stumbled upon this place. Since we didn't have a reservation, they weren't sure if they could seat us but the hostess was so kind that she sat us at the bar while she looked over the night's reservations to see if they had space. While we waited, we enjoyed complimentary marinated olives, spiced nuts, and other snacks.They found us a small table and we were ready to eat! Trusting our Spanish waitress who'd work there for years, we allowed her to bring her favorite dishes to our table. She suggested the mackerel with coconut salad and peanuts, scallops with pork belly and apple, twice-cooked baby chicken with lemon salt and chili sauce, roasted aubergine with saffron yogurt and pickled chili, butternut squash, courgette and feta fritters with cardamom yogurt, and burrata with coriander seeds and white balsamic. Everything was boldly seasoned, expertly prepared, and meticulously plated. The quality of food was phenomenal. Along with the meal, we tried their ginger cocktails and mocktails. Although we were pretty full after our dinner, we couldn't not order a couple of sweet things. We had the chocolate cake with orange oil and creme fraiche, along with the caramel and roasted peanut ice cream, chocolate sauce, and peanut brittle. The peanut brittle reminded us of the rock candy from our childhood. It "popped" on our tongues when we ate it.The service was incredible and the food was divine. Yes, the meal was expensive but it was definitely worth it.

photos.caption: Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Chocolate cake with orange oil and crime fraiche
Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Caramel and roasted peanut ice cream, chocolate sauce, and peanut brittle
Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Scallops with pork belly and yuzu sauce

lGU2m43MwmLVJykuIzAT5w.text: NOPI is nothing if not versatile - dates, business meetings, group dinners, celebrations - they definitely do it all.On my first visit I dined downstairs with my BFF and her partner and we tried every veg item on the menu plus three desserts (they're vegetarians). I knew I had to come back.On my second visit I dined upstairs and my dining companion was 45 minutes late, which somehow didn't seem as awful as it sounds in the soft glow of the dining room.The third time ended up being the charm for me with NOPI, my dining companion on that visit said he'd give NOPI a sixth star if he could. And we've been back many times together since.Make sure to book a table at NOPI - I recommend reserving downstairs. It's communal, more casual and allows you to make new friends.Pay close attention to the vegetable options on the menu (even if you're a major meat masticator). I love the baby chicken (and you should order it) but I've always been blown away by the unique and super interesting vegetable preparations at NOPI- they can do magic with broccolini, beets, cauliflower and seemingly anything pulled from the ground.

1tLIHmUcSnJDtfsz53jHcQ.text: Sat at the bar for a light dinner and was blown away.  Delicious Aubergine with yogurt and Moroccan spices and the twice cooked chicken paired with a nice Palestinian red made for a wonderful experience.

i9F89MjISxEBYu631rXXxg.text: Went for a late lunch, which was the only time available for an upstairs reservation and that was fine with us: jetlag helped! We ordered from the dishes to share selection and came away with 5 plates that were absolutely delicious, cooked to perfection and left us more than satisfied, except that we were then dying to come back from more - and they were sold out for the weekend we were still in London!Beetroot and gorgonzola; courgette and manoori fritters; valdeon cheesecake; twice cooked baby chicken and the pastille of beef shin... We long to return.

sOsUAbuX4l3jLTzdX76z9w.text: The name Ottolenghi is synonymous with culinary rapture in my household, a status achieved through our home cooking of his sublime, complex dishes; our frequent ogling of his vivid cookbook photos; and our appreciation of the compelling personal stories and behind the scenes commentary accompanying many of his recipes.   To say expectations were high going into my recent lunch at NOPI -- my first time in an Ottolenghi restaurant -- would be the understatement of the year.  The feast was sumptuous, beautiful, and memorable, and every single ingredient -- from the cuts of meat and stalks of vegetables to the subtle condiments and deftly sprinkled spices -- was purposeful and perfect.  Navigating the menu was impossible, like choosing from thirty secret doors, each concealing an unknown but assured fortune.   We selected a combination of plates from the meat, vegetables, and sides.  The only way we could possible narrow down choices was to sorrowfully sacrifice the mains, 'nibbles,' and fish, and what we did try was astonishing.I could rhapsodize at length about each of the dishes.  The highlights among the vegetables were the courgette (aka zucchini) and manouri fritters with cardamom yoghurt, and the crushed butterbeans with muhammara and walnuts.  The fritters were crisp on the outside and very moist on the inside, with a subtle infusion of cardamom in the fritter and the yogurt for good measure.  The earthy, coarsely crushed butterbeans were enlived by the robust muhammara, a traditional Syrian pepper sauce:  plenty of zing, but not overwhelming spice.  The twice-cooked baby chicken with lemon myrtle salt and chili sauce and the pork belly with pineapple and long pepper chutney and winter sour greens were our favorite meats.  I don't really have to say much about these dishes -- imagine the juxtaposition of ingredients assembled with care, creativity, and expertise, and you'll conjure the fantastic results.  The pork belly was especially interesting and well-executed, with a mind-boggling range of flavors.The vegetable highlight was char-grilled purple sprouting broccoli, a vegetable I'd yet to encounter in my life but hope to meet again, with the divine combination of tahini and miso folded generously over, around and under each stalk and floret.  We eschewed the more intense chocolate desserts and the undoubtedly toothsome financiers, opting instead for a palate cleanser of sorts, a Chinese dessert known as tau fu fa.  Normally made with soft tofu, Ottolenghi has taken coconut milk and set it in the fashion of panna cotta, topping it with sliced fresh coconut and mango and with ginger gula gawa, a potion of uncertain but celestial origin.

photos.caption: Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Pork belly paradise.
Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Purple Sprouted Broccoli.  Miso.  Tahini.

PVIeI2vW_Pnu1U6z2HPosg.text: I must have walked straight past this place a dozen times and although the front is clean and crisp it doesn't scream restaurant to me! Luckily when a friend came to visit we decided to book a table for brunch (after scouring Yelp reviews for brunch in that area).The interior is beautiful; bright golds and whites along with lovely wooden tables, and it's so light and spacious. The service was also first class with very friendly attentive staff.We were sat at a table for two at the front of the restaurant (you can also book a spot down at the communal table by the kitchens which looks fun) and were immediately handed glasses of water - this is an instant plus in my book! We were then given our menus and enough time to peruse. Although the brunch menu is fairly small there are a few things on there which are a little different and totally delicious sounding so it took me a while to decide. The waitress also offered explanations where necessary, of which I had as they have an amazing sounding black rice & coconut milk dish that I wanted a little more clarity on (by the way it's served warm). In the end my friend went for scrambled egg on toast and I went for the French toast. Both were amazing! Be warned the French toast is very fragrant (which I loved). We also each ordered their fresh mint tea which was so refreshing. In total it came to £13 each with tip and we were well and truly satisfied. I can't wait to go back to try more of their breakfast items (brisket hash & shackshuka) as well as their lunch & dinner menu.

photos.caption: Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom
Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom
Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom

o-h5BczqhkVvPG8EGlPvWA.text: So because we were in London we had to try at least two of Ottolenghi's restaurants.We decided to come here for breakfast to get the Shakshuka.  It didn't disappoint and was amazingly flavorful.  We also loved the mochas, they were rich but not too sweet.  I only wish I could have tried everything on the menu.Additionally, the staff was very friendly.

photos.caption: Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Amazing Mocha
Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Fruit!
Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Shakshuka

9HTTORfFEszygauvt7i05w.text: Make a reservation for "upstairs" (since there are communal tables downstairs). Nice layout, great space. The eggplant and roasted onion squash are to die for.

3qsO4TgyIz-iD5cC79VAig.text: Heard lots of good things about this Ottolenghi guy, celebrity chef, trend setter, businessman extraordinaire etc. I saw his first cookbook and his Mediterranean inspired foods look and sound fabulous. So off we went to NOPI to be wowed. Didn't happen.Hip Soho stylish location is busy. Servers do a nice job but nothing special. Food was good but nothing exceptional for the prices and portion sizes. Small selection of drinks, wine and a few beers. We ordered about 10 dishes, a good portion of the menu. Nothing disappointed but didn't wow. If you slather enough goat cheese and herbs  on anything it will taste good. Many non celebrity Chicago restaurants are doing a better job with similar, creative Mediterranean inspired menus (e.g. Fig & Olive) have much bigger menu & alcohol selections, bigger and brighter spaces and better price / value balance.

photos.caption: Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Not a buffet. Their cold plate serving station is located in the reception area as you walk in
Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom

0zjD5mBRwO-M1MA1LXxaJQ.text: Heard about Ottolenghi a few months ago when my uncle came to town and was taken there by one of his Italian friends - they both raved about it, but to be honest that was it, didn't really think much of it. It wasn't until my boyfriends parents came to visit from the Netherlands that we decided to give it a try - Ottolenghi is my mother-in-law's favorite chef! We had no choice! I did a bit of research, because turns out he has about 5 different places around town! Nopi seemed like a good choice for a proper lunch. Let's start with the decor - all white, simple but classy. Proper tables upstairs, whilst downstairs you can see into the kitchen but have one big table to share - not a issue at all, but worth keeping in mind it is somewhat louder downstairs. The toilets definitely require a mention! Mirrors everywhere!!! Looks good but have to say a little confusing! I might even suggest going to the loo before you start drinking! Or remember to bring your phone in with you in case you need to make an emergency save me phone all!!! But the food, that's what we are interested about, isn't it? Fantastic Mediterranean Middle Eastern food, with wonderful wordly flavours with a serious focus on vegetables, but amazing fish & meat options too, do not worry! Really extraordinary flavours! Highly highly recommend. I even went to buy the cookbook straight after! Highlights are most definitely the courgette manouri fritters, the octopus was delicious. The lamb sweetbreads, oh la la! Not sure if you are familiar with that but its basically the thymus & pancreas of the lamb, might not sound appetizing but don't ask questions and just go for it, honestly! The different vegetables and sides are also very very good. Maybe worth mentioning the truffle potenta chips weren't quite as exciting as I hoped, but the tomato salad however basic you may think it is, it is not!!Have most definitely decided to try out the rest of his restaurants!! Will keep you updated! :)

CkDdRsGvy9iNA8iF_-apmQ.text: One of my best friends just got dubbed Elite. So I gave her a restaurant challenge for my Birthday. Obviously, she used Yelp, and took me to NOPI. It was amazing, and you should go too.My mother is a MASSIVE fan of Ottolenghi, and has been experimenting from his Jerusalem book for the past 3 years. My mum is an amazing cook so I was really excited about this.The venue is a great representation of the food you will be served: simple, but tasteful and original. You feel that you are in a nice place, but didn't have an over-the-top feel to it - you feel welcome.The menu is divided into 3 main sections:- Nibbles- Mains- SharingMy friend and I having similar culinary tastes, we decided to go for a mix of dishes from the Nibbles and Sharing, and we went for:- Vegetables with avocado: as simple as it gets, but with amazing seasoning that just brings out the flavour of amazing products. Just make sure you like radish and baby carrots.- Prosciutto: good prosciutto doesn't need much. It was perfect- Burrata: With grilled coriander. Oh. My- Aubergine with yoghurt- Pork Shoulder Croquette: SO TENDER AND TASTY- ScallopsMay I also recommend the Vitovska wine? It is an orange wine that goes really well with the sharing platter. I would say that we ordered the perfect amount of food to feel full but not stuffed. The products used are incredibly tasty and fresh, and with flavours you wouldn't usually be used to - which turns the whole meal into a great culinary experience.When can we go back?

photos.caption: Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. - Sourdough with olive oil (complimentary) - Pio Tosini Prosciutto,beer piquillo - Vegetable crudites, avocado

AtULaYixOiZkfrlhlEGiEg.text: I'm so sad to write this review... Let me preface this - I love chef Ottolenghi. I have almost all of his cookbooks and I love them all. So when we were planning a trip to London, a visit to Nopi was a must. I was so excited to be there and I really wanted to just love every spoonful of my dinner here. First off, the service was amazing. Our waiter was very helpful and very attentive to us the whole time we were there and we enjoyed the ambiance of the place as well, with white and brass colors, and the visit the bathroom was a trip (mirrors, that's all I'll say). We opted for his vegetarian appetizers all of which were displayed up front and you could see them before you ordered them. We opted for roasted aubergines and sweet potatoes. Both were ok. Perhaps my expectations were too high, but was waiting for explosions of flavor,and while they were both solid, they weren't very memorable and I think his cookbooks have much better recipes that could have replaced those. For entrees, we chose duck breast and sea bass. The duck was amazing. That definitely hit all the notes and expectations I had and we simply loved it. The sea bass we felt was overpowered by the spices in the spiced butter it was covered with and ultimately left us longing for something different. We ended with the chocolate ganache desert on recommendation of our waiter and it didn't disappoint. It was excellent. Overall, there were some highs and some flats on this one. The rating is based on this specific meal, and perhaps had we opted for other items on the menu, it would be higher. I still remain a big fan of the chef, and I will still come back next time we're in London and perhaps try different items on the menu.

photos.caption: Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Roasted aubergines, sweet potatoes, duck breast and sea bass.

t-CLpZpxGC6nhwi34xKvFA.text: As one of Ottenghis big fans, I would have to say I was disappointed.  The food was very good, as you would expect, but it was really no different than Ottolenghi in Islington, except the prices were much higher.   Location dependent I suppose but I would see no reason to go back.

eB6J30c6Zz-d-PSDs74Oag.text: I was very much looking forward to eating here after being such a huge fan of the books. Ate here with a group of 8 on a lovely evening. Reception and waitstaff was very nice and accommodating. Food was pretty, and good. Not amazing, but good. Portions were small, prices were large for what you received. So I ordered everything on the menu 2-3 times over. Nice presentation, but would have expected more punch to the food as it lacked typical Mediterranean flavor a I would have expected. With all the rave reviews, it must have been an off night. I may be tempted to return here perhaps on my own first next time. It was a little embarrassing to organize such a grand evening with clients only to have a luck luster dinner.

photos.caption: Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. So pretty and delicious!
Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Food did not last long on the table!

OO4eC-E4YtA0eRGd_wRUmQ.text: Had high expectations. Most plates were very nice, chickpea pancake was a total miss. Where the experience fell down was our servers wine recommendations, one almost undrinkable.

3MARjMsotZVDa0N2EiB2WQ.text: Mediterranean style fine dining quality food for a wonderful relaxing lunch date. 4.5 starsFood: 4.5 Service: 4.5 Atmosphere: 4.5Cost to worth it rating: 4 (small sharing plates for lunch: 9.5-15 pounds, mains: ~23)Opentableable: yes Cool bathroom signs: yes (check out my collection on Instagram as signsbathroom)Return worthiness: yesHighlights:- Courgette and manouri fritters: fried zucchini and cheese ball was my favorite item. Crispy with some texture on the outside and stuffed with shredded zucchini and a tart Greek style cheese. Flavors were unique and worked well together. 5 stars - Eggplant: 3 thick grilled slices were so soft yet firm enough to cut through. Mint yogurt and almonds made a nice accompaniment. 4.5 stars- Octopus: grilled to create some char flavor which is my favorite way to eat this seafood. 4 stars- Short ribs: tender stewy meat. 4 stars- Asparagus: grilled and served with pumpkin seeds. 4 stars- Polenta: thick polenta fries surprisingly held up with a form exterior yet were still mooshy inside. Mild truffle flavor mixed with the cornmeal. 3.5 stars- Atmosphere: all white long room with a wood plank table for those standing and some blank and white movie projected in a small area above the stairs.- Service: delightful guy gave suggestions and was always there to refill my waterLowlights: - There are 2 separate booking for Nopi and Nopi-downstairs yet which can be confusing. The menu is the same at least for lunch. Upstairs has standard tables and downstairs has large communal tables by the kitchen.Fully enjoyed my lunch and would love to come back and try this famous chef's other restaurants.

O5AebQQXAetmBKv0-mCKSg.text: Phenomenal food, excellent service, lovely ambiance. We dressed up but you could come more casually dressed. We had a reservation and were seated immediately. Recommend roasted aubergine, truffle polenta chips. Very vegetarian friendly.

4LgXHSa1xavRnHgB2kd_bQ.text: NOPI is an elegant restaurant with wonderful service, and even though it's not the most important thing, some of the most gorgeous bathrooms I've ever seen!  A bit disorienting as every surface is covered in mirrors!  Wait, if I say they're gorgeous and they're covered in mirrors, I don't want you to think I'm trying to say it's actually me that's gorgeous!  It really is the decor!  Okay, never mind, moving on.Before I forget, the olive oil that they give you with the bread is unreal good.  And you can buy it in the restaurant.  I think it's Sicilian - called Planeta.  Don't leave without a bottle, I think it's only £15 and it may change your life.We had a wide variety of dishes, I remember the roast okra was some of the best veg I've ever had (it's the chili and maple flavor), so creative and just fabulous.  The roasted butternut squash was also extremely good.  The beef short rib and the twice-cooked baby chicken were both lovely too (beef especially as I recall), but I think this is a truly stunning place for vegetables.  No surprise, as Ottolenghi excels in that arena.  The burrata with sweet peaches, the courgette fritters with cardamom yoghurt.... the chef truly knows his/her way around a vegetarian kitchen, and it really shows.  Everything is bound to be good here.  Plates are small for the price, but you do get lovely service and incredibly fresh, gorgeous food.  Highly recommended for vegetarians or those with vegetarian-leanings.

ZBYpuo3AIvD1Oba1UOhZdg.text: For the sake of this review let's generalise for a minute and split the world of restoration into two categories: the one that has dishes made tasty by a variety of strong flavours and ingredients aplenty, and the one that focuses on few ingredients, but REALLY good ones. Nopi is definitely part of the latter category. It's your typical 'pay a lot for smallish portions' and yet you leave the restaurant with a singing palate. I took one of my best friends there for her birthday and I'm really happy I did: we ordered two starters/nibbles dishes and 4 dishes to share, which included a bit of everything: from veggie crudités to burrata, from aubergines to scallops, and every thing was spot-on. The flavours were incredible. Nicely presented too, which I always like. We were actually wondering where can they possibly source such good and fresh ingredients. We had lunch upstairs (I believe there is a downstairs too, with communal tables). The room is bright and airy, there's space to move around the tables without knocking someone's vino down with your butt (don't ask) and the tables for two can actually accommodate two people PLUS the food. Amazing, right? I'm so used to having to push plates around to fit everything in some restaurants. We also tried their orange wine, which was very yummy. I'd definitely go back, probably to try something from their dinner menu. Very impressed, bravo NOPI!

photos.caption: Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom
Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom
Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom

XquDxuV_4L2-tYhZkO6jmg.text: I can't believe that I'm about to say that I was disappointed in NOPI, but I was. Considering how complex and intimidating Ottolenghi's cookbooks are, I was just expecting a little bit more from him. The food wasn't bad, as Yelp suggests for three stars, it was A-OK. I found that the courgette fritters were way too aggressively seasoned. They were super salty. We also had the burrata, which was actually my favorite. It's hard to screw up a big blob of cheese. It was accented with coriander seeds, which were great for taste and texture, and blood orange helped cut through the creaminess of the cheese. For my main, I had a roasted eggplant dish and a side of the lentils. The eggplant was actually quite good, but the lentils were almost inedibly salted. Adam had the baby chicken, which he seemed to like a lot. We finished with a dessert that was like an apple crumble with a celery gelato. This is maybe where my expectations were crushed most. I have had celery flavored gelato and ice cream before, and this just really didn't pack a lot of the flavor we were hoping for. Considering the price, I'm not sure that we'd make a repeat visit to NOPI.

CJcsfHfBrTEj_yEt6K0TpA.text: I've been a huge fan of Ottolenghi's recipes ever since receiving the "Jerusalem" cookbook as a gift a couple years ago. I subsequently have bought every one of his other cookbooks and utilize them as frequently as possible. I love taking the time to make his intricate, beautiful dishes for Sunday night family dinners. So, when I booked a trip to London recently, I knew going to one of his restaurants was a must on the itinerary - We decided on Nopi. It was hands-down my best dining experience in London. We sat upstairs, and it was beautiful. Every aspect of the décor was stunning, and clearly a lot of thought was put into making the dining space feel elegant yet cozy. I'm glad we sat upstairs for a more intimate experience, but the downstairs communal table overlooking the kitchen looked fun, too! For lunch, we ordered the burrata/peach, chickpeas and squash with feta, scallops, the chicken with chilli sauce and truffle polenta chips with garlic aioli. The flavors of all the dishes were outstanding. The chickpeas were my favorite because it was a warm, hearty dish packed with lots of Mediterranean flavor. I also has a carrot/ginger juice that was quite refreshing. Everything was coursed out perfectly, and the staff was attentive and friendly. If I ever return to London, I'd definitely go back to Nopi.

f7ZBfH-Uw8RgCihl_q4iGQ.text: We had a reservation for a special dinner at NOPI. The reservation was fairly last minute so we had to take a 9:30 seating, but it was absolutely worth it. The service was attentive, the food was exploding with flavour, and the ambiance was perfect - quiet, not too "posh"/"stuffy" but still high end. One of the dishes we ordered wans't available and instead we got 3 other things on the house. It was a delightful gesture.We had aubergine, fish, the "cheesecake" dessert, and a number of other delights. The flavours and the food was outstanding. So much so that in the end I bought a signed copy of Ottolenghi's second book.The price, by the way, while on the high side is definitely acceptable for a fancy London restaurant - around 40-45 GBP per person, including a lot of appetizers and a bottle of wine and service.

qzUEuDgE6eeqTlSV9r9qDw.text: Awesome food!!! Highly recommended if you are vegetarian or pescatarian.Drinks were great too!

RBbmc825He2UHzR9q1v7Jw.text: Our bride had a little party in her honor here, there were 10 of us for lunch.She had given me some Ottolenghi cookbooks recently so I sort of knew what to expect in terms of innovation, style and food and it was all right on! It was organized so we could order from the regular menu. All the food was beautifully presented and innovative and flavor variety. Our bride was vegan and they accommodated w.out problems. The service was very wonderful, they were nice to us, the place was full but not churring busy, and we had a long table on the street window side of the room. LOVED the decor, (as artist/designer myself) there was no detail left un curated. All in all lovely! would go back in a flash.  Finally the bathroom. Is this not the best bathroom in the entire world? a little jewel box that i include here.

AAmQczXs0ywM2EXy8r9yyg.text: From the moment we arrived we loved the atmosphere, the staff and especially the food. The staff is very attentive, knowledgable and the food is absolutely delicious. The burrata was to die for, as was the alcohol free cranberry cocktail.

photos.caption: Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Sea bass with lovage sauce, fennel and roast tomatoes

yQ8jE-LByuHXoXHTe-6yvA.text: WHOA cool bathroom, bro.  But seriously, check out the bathroom, and good luck finding your way out of it (hint, lots of mirrors).Absolutely loved it here, we ordered 6 small plates and each were memorable.Roasted aubergine (£9)- my favorite. Three slices of roasted aubergine with pesto and fetaCheesecake (£11) with beets- my second favorite. A quiche like consistency with beets on top.Spiced hake (£12.5)- wrapped in banana and flaked off very delicately.Truffled polenta chips (£4.5)- MUST TRY.Baby chicken (£8.5)- came with two dippings, lemon salt and chilli sauce and both were perfect.Duck Breast (£11.5)- tender and came with beer butterFor dessert we ordered the £7.5 Sticky rice with caramelized banana and £8 Marshamallow concoction with liquor jelly, both of which were inhaled almost immediately.  Food coma never felt so amazing.

5tjb8YlhYuImyrX3XG8iXQ.text: Excellent interesting food for reasonable price. Will be there again for sure in my next visit.  The fried polenta was incredible, the cheese soufflé was to die for - still thinking  about the taste. The place is pleasant to enjoy a quiet evening with friends and eat incredibly well!!!

i4MiKcaLDd6wLiWhT1ELYA.text: Barged in on a Tuesday evening at 6:20pm and requested the pre-theater prix fixe menu -- and was promptly seated at a lovely table for two near the back bar area (under a skylight).  The pre-theater menu is priced per person, and served family style (communal plates).  First two courses were served together:  (1) sweet potato with goat cheese, and (2) eggplant with fromage blanc and pomagranite seeds.  OMG.  The sweet potato with goat cheese = brilliant combination.  I would not have thought of it in a million years, and it was delicious.  The eggplant was good too, but not quite as inspired as the sweet potato (did I mention that sweet potatoes are one of my favorite foods, so perhaps I'm biased...). Third course was a pan fried mackeral, which was really well done -- crispy on the outside, tender on the inside and really mackerally.  MMMM.  The fourth and fifth courses were served together:  (4) pressed baby chicken (think of 1/2 of a cornish game hen size) served with peppered salt and sweet-sour mince (not sauce), and (5) duck confit with a plum preserve.  The chicken was so cute (e.g., small portion) -- but delicious with the sauce and salt accent.  The duck confit was a bit strange.  There was a mint note that just didn't fit with the plum or the duck, and I'm still not sure of the source.  Service was impeccable.  The only off note was that there was a really long pause between the 3rd and 4th courses.  Perhaps 20 minutes.  We did tell the hostess that we had to leave by 7:30pm to catch our show, and we left at 7:20pm -- so that was perfect (no, we were not rushed or nervous about the time).  I would definitely come back to NOPI, and would definitely consider taking clients here as well (it's both a date and business ambiance).  Great atmosphere, great service, great food!  p.s. -- look at my star distribution in my profile, I'm not a pushover who gives 5 stars all the time!!

photos.caption: Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Course 5:  Duck confit with plum preserves
Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Course 4: Pressed "baby" chicken
Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Course 3: Fried mackerel

IAxxrVPpND_I11ZbV7Wttw.text: The dishes range from 2 to 4 stars, so I'm being generous by rounding way up because if I lived here, I'd revisit and find what dishes work across the board to make it a stellar 4-star restaurant.Cute Soho restaurant. For tourists like me, go behind Hamleys on Regent and you'll find NOPI, which stands for "North of Piccadilly." I wasn't pleased with our greeting. It was as if we didn't belong there without reservations, yet there were 5-7 tables open the entire time we dined there. They seated us at the bar, which is weird, given my daughter is 11...but I wasn't going to correct them given that the hostesses were a wee bit snobbish. Aside from that, the service at the bar was great and the food ranged from just OK to excellent. I am rating on food and bar service only (not the above mentioned snobbery).They recommend 3 small savory plates per person, so we ordered 6 between us and shared them all. Plates are nicely split into categories: Veg, fish, meat, sweets. I wish we had ordered more of the veg plates and skipped the meat. But that's hindsight.We tried:--Winter coleslaw w/macadamia and mango (very good)--Five spice tofu (STUNNING! Wish we had ordered 3 of these and skipped some of the others. Only bummer is you literally only get 2 small squares of tofu. Trust me, you'll want more. Don't let the "tofu" part dissuade you.)--Seared prawns, fennel, feta (just Ok)--Seared scallops, fennel puree, apple salsa (good)--Slow cooked pork belly, coco bean cassoulet, salsa verde (just OK)--Roasted beef sirloin (just OK)Were I to come back (and I would if I lived here)...I'd make it for happy hour only and have another great Lychee and Grapefruit Cooler with vodka and mint and lemon. And then I'd order a couple of the 5-spice tofu dishes and some of the other veg dishes that sounded great, but we didn't try....and call it a night.Oh, and I do not jest, whether you need to or not, visit the bathrooms. You've never seen anything like it. I wish I had taken my camera in there...

photos.caption: Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom

7ttch4u43qv9djZglp_DzA.text: DELICIOUS! Fantastic experience, beautiful food, soooo unique. The cauliflower was excellent, the cheesecake is a MUST and we loved the octopus. Can't wait to go back. Communal table downstairs would be really fun for a group.

qOHL62tW1gMgavtdloFGrw.text: This place rockets to the top of my favourite places to eat in London, and I don't say that lightly.We went here last night for my boyfriend's birthday, and had an unbelievable night.I booked online and went for the upstairs sitting, where you get individual tables, as opposed to the big shared benches downstairs next to the kitchen. Both lovely, just different in atmosphere. When you walk in, it's immediately a nice place to be. A white and yellow colour scheme with natural light makes it feel airy and spacious. Gold finishings add to this, with marble flooring and LOADS of space between seats. The best place to sit is the first table of two, at the back of the restaurant on the right hand side.The bathrooms are a mirrored headtrip too, totally disorientating and a load of fun.So, we sit, we order a pineapple & sage martini (which has a somewhat spicy kick to it) and a rum &pistachio cocktail. We're not rushed, the drinks are delicious, and we admire our surroundings.We're brought a complimentary plate of hummus with aubergine and bread with olive oil. Simple, but delicious. The oil was super green, the hummus absolutely perfect.Our waitress was attentive but not pushy, knew the menu inside out and indulged all of our questions.We went for roast asparagus with a smoky tomato sauce and broccolini with lemon mash from the vegetable selection. They recommend three dishes per person, and I'd agree. I love simplicity, and the menu here is divided into three sections.One from each. Easy. Anyway. You know you're somewhere special when a chef manages to make vegetables that tasty. Both dishes were stunning. I've never tasted anything like that lemon mash.From the fish selection we had the mackerel  with red lentils (yum) and prawns (huge and meaty, but with delicate flavour). For meat we had beef sirloin (obviously) and twice-baked chicken, which deserves a special mention for being juicy and tender.The wine list is equally eclectic, divided into sections such as 'off the beaten track', from which we chose a beautiful Italian red.We chatted to our waitress while we switched out an initial crab dish for the prawns, since it wasn't to our taste. She replaced it without fuss, and we weren't charged. My other half asked to keep a menu (since they're printed with the date and it was a nice keepsake for his birthday). Then when our deserts came out, there was a candle a piped chocolate birthday message on his. A lovely touch, and something we didn't even ask for.For me, the desert was the star of the show. I recently had the best ice cream I've ever tasted at da Polpo, so my bar is high, but I have to say that the pineapple galette with coconut ice cream at Nopi was phenomenal. It was divine. We also had the coffee pecan financiers with maple cream. Both dishes were made fresh and were hot from the oven.Sure it's pricey here (we paid £125 including service), but, you get what you pay for. The experience is fantastic and well worth EVERY penny.

mGy9Gl5aTr5x_VRUAl8zxw.text: I came across this restaurant by change, and happy to do so.  The only disadvantage of such matter is we were unable to dine-in the main hall, instead sharing big table in basement near the kitchen.So don't forget to reserve your table before arriving there.If you are lucky to catch these dishes before the menu change, please do try them, you won't regret it.STARTER:- Courgette and manouri fritters, cardamom yoghurt- Spriced buttermilk cod, urid dahl, bergamot oilMAINS:- Whole twice cooked baby chicken, lemon myrtle salt, chili sauce.- Vegetable crudites, crushed peans, Belper Knolle.
