uXNIOK7duPpic6VAGJ7aIA.text: Beautiful restaurant hosting higher standard cooking from ottelenghi. The place is golden and shiny the food is not the best looking but generally pretty tasty. The bar was very decent on my last visit.

aaTdgSOnj21Ls5zLaU_JDQ.text: I was very excited to check out Nopi, afterall Ottolenghi in Islington remains one of my favourite restaurants. Nopi continues with the small plate theme---lots of excellent tapas-sized dishes to choose from. The standouts (see pics) included the grilled sea bream, braised pig cheek (I wish we ordered 2 of this, it was fall off your fork tender) and the goat cheese/asparagus starter. For dessert be sure get an espresso martini and the freshly baked financiers.I recommend eating in the sightly more informal downstairs dining room, which consists of 2 very large common tables right in the middle of the pantry. You get to hear (and possibly) see the chefs hard at work in the open kitchen, and also get a chance to interact with other diners. And do check out the toilets...the mirrors are a total trip.Service was excellent---prompt, polite, and oh so knowledgeable about the menu. Our waitress also allowed us to sample a few wines before selecting a bottle. She also went out of her way to accomodate my friend's allergies.Only downside...it's ridiculously expensive for what you get...try 8 quid for a small plate of broccolini! Be sure to bring that expense account!

photos.caption: Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom
Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom
Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom

X1uCHZhQtolX5YV9x-t19A.text: When I return to London I am making it a personal vendetta to dine at all of the restaurants this chef (I forget his name, for shame) owns and operates. This particular place was tapas style.  My friend and I sat at a communal table downstairs, the ambience was mood-lit and it was enjoyable. Everyone tells me that England isn't particularly known for their cuisine, but I beg to differ. I really enjoyed every restaurant I dined in, this one the most. The food tasted gourmet. Everything was fresh and hot, the ingredients were delicious, the flavors were delicately paired. Just thinking about it makes my mouth water. The service is pretty good as well.All I can say is don't hesitate. Just go, sit in, enjoy the atmosphere with your mates and try the AUBERGINE!

UGl3844sUj0XcwdEUPhIfA.text: We had dinner at Nopi earlier this week and I was very disappointed... I have both of Ottolenghi's books, (Plenty & Plenty More) and each time I've cooked something, its come out great- so I may have been expecting a lot more at his London restaurant - unfortunately it wasn't.  The cod fish entree was so-so, and the appetizers were nice but not as nice as it sounded on the menu. I was told that produce in London isn't as great as what you get in California and mostly imported from neighboring countries -we are spoiled for choice by farmers markets and produce grown an hour away in CA, so minimal cooking can bring intense flavors - so I'm just assuming thats what it was. I do love his cookbooks, his veg paella is still my fav but I'm not sure Nopi was.

o8A8Qt_QaOqRNlyvYKC-fg.text: Quite disappointed here!We came here because of the great and raving Yelp reviews. The location is nice, stylish and pretty busy. Once we got seated it took a while till we were served with some water.The waitress was friendly and helpful. We started with a few bites and were super disappointed with pretty average olives and a standard nut mix (in some restaurants that would have been complementary especially considering the low quality). It took them a very long time to bring the next dish which was a pre-made aubergine salad. The station for the salad was basically next to our table but it took them whooping 20mins to load that into a plate and bring it over. The salad itself was not very flavorful and flat - nothing special.This experience continued when we got the burrata. We didn't like the seeds on top at all and the burrata itself had an unusual flavor. When we were asked how we liked it we mentioned the burrata and our waitress got it off the bill - that was great service.The chicken was a bit too dry and the rib a bit too undercooked. The best dish was the sea bass - but that was an OKish dish considering the price.The best here was the friendly waitress and some great cocktails. The food was not good at all, especially at this price level.This restaurant seems to live off the celebrity name of the owner. You can definitely do better in SoHo.

x2iGZuA34p1RX6py75XUWA.text: What a meal. What a night. What a birthday! This place really made my birthday night, and was a perfect setting with two large communal table's set downstairs - resembled eating in your own home kitchen, albeit if you lived in a really fancy place.The menu - both food and wine - were as good as expected. A range of 'half sized' plates allowed for a great selection to arrive and to try many different dishes.Stand out performers were the duck, the pork belly, scallops, twice cooked chicken and the truffled polenta chips. Oh my the chips. HAVE THESE! Amazing.Oh and be sure to check out the bathrooms! You'll see why. Not sure what impressed one of the girls in our group more, the bathrooms, or the Irish waiter. You're choice.Great place, no pretension, great food, no stress. Will be sure to be back!

pNHL5FIupuFMQCOFw2CGwQ.text: As my friend Elly V. once said, "WHAT IS THIS MAJESTIC PLACE?"The second I took a bite of my pumpkin appetizer, I didn't even have a chance to swallow before the words "5 stars" fell out of my mouth. All I kept thinking was that if this was any indicator of the rest of the meal, I should just raise my flag from now. The decor was simple and classy. Not very inviting or homely but clean and sophisticated.The service was great.But it's all about the food. Two definite musts: Pork Sirloin is the bomb and helllooooooo brussell sprouts. Every dish was a unique combination with a HOLY BURST OF INTENSE FLAVOURS, Batman. I was left in disbelief that the possibility of the next would taste superior to the previous and just when I thought the bar could not be raised any higher, I was proved wrong. With each bite, our eyes dimmed closed, mouths dropped open and a deep exhale was inevitable. Is this real life? Is this heaven? This IS heaven. Alas, it IS real life and now my favourite restaurant of all time. Seriously though, I will now forever recommend Nopi to EVERYONE. Visitor and locals alike. Everyone that has taste-buds, a semi-large wallet and a love for delicious food. It should be noted that while the food is share-able, you probably won't want to share. In fact, if eating with me, you might get stabbed with a fork if you try to take the last bite of anything. Especially when it comes to dessert. You have been warned.The only disappointment was the house wine. For what this restaurant was and what we experienced, I was expecting something more of the house wine but I guess if anything had to be lacking, I'm glad it was just that.Dreams are made of this place.Protips:+ It's a perfect place for a romantic date. + Check out the bathrooms.Also, NOPI: If you keep delivering food this unbelievably tasty, I have nothing more to say other than shut up and take my money.

UuXmtexrxDfT_GHs8h5mwQ.text: Off the charts- the nibblers, starters and main courses were unique and full of thought and love. I had olives, pork crochets, short ribs and duck- service was great. Space is loud, but atmosphere is top shelf. If you don't know what your in the mood for- or you are positive you don't want the same old food- NOPI is the place.

_Uc05p3cPQcxwFZ9NDZx7A.text: This was very good. We got:- Olives- Onion dip- Smoked beef- Burrata- Butternut squash- Fritters- OctopusThe highlights for me were the burrata, beef, and octopus. (I'm always scared when I get octopus, but it's always so good.) The only thing I really wasn't crazy about were the fritters, which had a sour cream and/or goat cheese-type cream as part of the filling, and that's generally not my favorite. But everything else was great, and I would definitely recommend going here.

6BQ23Y_Q_QJrnU6EtlpY7Q.text: Interesting place. I can see how others might rave about the food, place, and service. All as expected. I'm torn, though, on whether to give a 3- or 4- star review. Scallops: three served on a plate. Delicious. Peppers: two large (or maybe three small) on a plate. Meh. Sirloin: three thin slices. Very good. For two people, maybe one more starter would have been better. Unfortunately, of the main dish selections for the evening jumped out at me and demanded my order. So, I decided to try something I'd never try at home: the chickpea pancake. A very nice, light, and appropriately spicy dish that reminded me of some of the more stellar falafel I've had in my travels. I can't complain, though I wouldn't (as some previous commenters have suggested) want to get on a plane and fly across the ocean for it. Not even inspired enough to buy the cookbook. So, just to help level set expectations, I'll go with a rounded down 3 (from a 3.5). Tasty, but perhaps not as worthy of the hype to get the 4th star.

kRAiAMtNsSb104itu6AXZA.text: A place - wonderful, beautifulA service - fast and very sweet waiters.Food - the most important part- very tasty, but (!) the portions are not big, just to know. We took 6 courses and a dessert it was pretty enough.The price - as for me too expensive.But it was worth it!!! The place was fully booked all the time that we were there, so book a table!

OqO46sHV0kE3W9LqwCjzNQ.text: In what I can only assume is driven by a strong US dollar and favorable airfare rates, it seems like everyone I know is taking a trip across the pond these days. We were on the early end of this recent fad (sure, you can call me a trendsetter, I'm OK with that), and when I hear anyone headed to London - friends, co-workers, straphangers, you name it - I give them one very firm recommendation: go to NOPI. It was easily the best meal I had in town, and those who have taken me up on my advice, have returned with the same all-around praise for this Soho stunner.I had made a booking some weeks in advance and mentioned in the notes it being an anniversary. When we arrived, the front of house warmly took our coats as if we were coming to see old friends at their well-curated home, and immediately put complimentary champagne in our hands, in recognition of our special occasion and thanking us for choosing to spend it with them. The dining room's decor was understated yet striking, white and gold everythang, with an open kitchen in the back. When I'd later venture downstairs, I would discover a livelier, more casual, communal set-up, and memorable toilets with angled mirrors, a washroom which seems to be "selfie central" and a destination all its own on Instagram.After my champagne came a cocktail order of their Pineapple and Absinthe Shrub. And then another. And another. And... I ended up having five of 'em throughout the night. You might say I really enjoyed this drink. It was made with pineapple, punch syrup, apple vinegar, absinthe, and a ginseng aperitif called Kamm & Sons I'm almost certain I'd never tried before. Anyway. Five of 'em.And if the interior design, service, and cocktails weren't special enough, we come to the cuisine. We ordered a handful of plates to share, and when we asked our waiter to make sure we didn't miss out on any musts, he wasted no time in recommending the Lemon Sole. It was the most simple dish we ate, but also the most sensational - perfectly cooked fish, swimming in burnt butter and just a hint of nori. And because the chef is known for his inventiveness and versatility specifically with vegetables, make sure to order the Roasted Aubergine, essentially halved eggplants stuffed with a mixture of yoghurt, black garlic, herbs, and pine nuts, and the Courgette and Manouri Fritters, a heartier take on fried zucchini.In fact, don't listen to me at all and order anything you want here. I'm that confident it'll be tremendous even if I haven't had it. In a global city as big as London, with God knows how many other restaurants, I'm 100% returning to NOPI next time I'm in town. And I promise you that's not the shrubs talking.

xESAUjplOemJHWEW0tXFIQ.text: I've waited years to visit an Ottolenghi restaurant and NOPI was 100% worth the wait. Exceptional everything: food, wine, service and atmosphere. I sat at the bar as I was traveling alone for work but didn't feel lonely at all. The servers at the bar were helpful and fun as were my bar guests who ended up sharing small plates with me. I had a light citrus salad with pink peppercorns which are a magical ingredient when used with restraint; signature zucchini and cheese fritters; and a small plate of sea bream cooked to perfection in a light broth. Every bite was incredible. Desserts looked terrific but I didn't save enough room. This is a must-go destination on any London trip.

SMfzs81ijYCVSL25isvFZw.text: Amazing meal.Started w the Cecina smoked beef, courgette fritters, then goat shawarma. All were delicious. The Aubergine + Tanarind was good, but the others were outstanding. Also excellent and honest service.

aBXIOrF7ixo_7A9GtUwt4A.text: I had lunch at NOPI two days in a row.  The food is amazing! The cheese pie is a must, but the service is not great. Tired.It takes away from what an amazing experience it could be.

2Vs96Wog_PlJWIdrA1KcfA.text: Loved our meal here.  We were downstairs which is a little more casual.  There are large counter tables.  We loved everything that we got.  The salad, vegetables, everything was awesome.  The cocktails were also good.  Seriously, everything was good.  This would be my number one choice restaurant to come back to when in the area today.  We went to a lot of excellent restaurants and this one stood out with a lot of options for vegetarians, good prices and I liked the big table style seating downstairs.

IsCLpP4blJig3M-e1jeNtQ.text: Well, I am not saying the food s bad here, but it could have been done better. We ordered several dishes but they were not as good as we expected...the environment s decent...not bad for group or couples. A medium choice in town to be honest...

CWE2k5gGntjlxGMft7XWjw.text: Nice, bright setting.  Two levels, both nicely laid out.Service was great and the food was on point.  The highlight was the Valdeon cheesecake.  Unexpectedly amazing.  Warm, cheesy, absolutely delicious.Also had the smoked beef, crisps, sea bass, chickpea pancake.  All nicely done.

bx6UT9byHeLkXdXOgCocvw.text: Lovely lunch. Our waiter Lucas was charming and the service was warm and knowledgeable. The crudités was beautiful, fresh and delicious. We also ordered the broccoli with miso and tahini, the green beans and savory cheesecake. For dessert, financier which were served warm with maple cream and espresso. All very special!

photos.caption: Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom

utQelq_AZ4Vhky4L7DUPow.text: I don't get it... People rave about this place but I found it to be lacking, mostly in the flavors of the food.I own the cookbook and have ogled photos of the restaurant for eons.  I thought I was in for a real treat with vegetable dishes that we're sure to deliver, but flavors were not all there. Many of the veggies were displayed as a cold anti pasta bar and yet still pricey. They were sitting out for hours and not made fresh to order.The cocktail that was a gin punch was remarkable and worth having more than one of. Chicken was very good. Cheesecake appetizer was also very good and unique. Okra was refreshing and flavorful.  Everything else I found to be ok if not unmemorable. Eggplant was my least favorite, followed by the zucchini fritters and butternut squash. Service was excellent and very friendly. Atmosphere was a nice blend of modern and inviting. All white brick walls with modern lighting.

YSlyHZ4HZDGcNT0WLZEArg.text: I ordered a Moscow Mule to drink and it was fantastic! For starters I ordered their beef option (I'm drawing a blank for the official name). The slices were heavenly and full of flavor!For my main, I order a small portion of the baby chicken and a large portion of the potato cakes. The baby chicken was INCREDIBLE! I wish I would've ordered the bigger portion. The meat melts in your mouth and the flavor is to die for. I absolutely loved it! The potato cakes were also great, but nothing to rave over.I should also mention that the service was great. I received my food very quickly.Dessert was excellent. I ordered the coffee and pecan financiers with maple cream. Very good!

5ZXgu8NZB7i8TzgAL8IhFQ.text: We are huge fans and cook from your cookbooks regularly. While in town visiting from Los Angeles had to come try the cuisine in person. From the moment we arrived we were treated well, the wait staff were incredibly knowledgeable and assisted us in selecting a perfect menu. Stand outs included the Aubergine, crispy potatoes and cheesecake! It was one of our best meals abroad and will be back!

photos.caption: Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom

t-qeBP49Gww-SQJLCXt0Zg.text: Nopi is a restaurant that offers a beautiful array of dishes that both look and taste lovely. The atmosphere is warm and intimate, and if you go downstairs they have a really long communal table. That's where I sat with my friend. I ordered the freekeh salad and it was large, delicious, and flavourful. It was a really lovely experience, and I would certainly go here again for a special occasion.

eCYYL8mn1h0lVmrVd5fx6Q.text: This is a place I've been to and used to love. I am not going to disagree on the food which is the main selling point, delicious dishes, usually exceeding already high expectations.However the service isn't quite as good, which is fine because I tend to value food over service, but there are limits. And our last visit was pretty much spoiled because of the exceedingly unfriendly service.Basically the very explicit body language made us feel very unwelcome, and this feeling was later confirmed when we were offered the bill before the dessert menu...Was it because it was a busy Sunday and staff was under stress, or because we were with a 3 year old, or just because that particular staff member was going through bad times? I don't know, but it was a bad experience, bad enough to stop eating there.

rWJd2an_rU8P0UPZtfbgvQ.text: This restaurant i can say " it is a landmark of London Restaurants " you must come and try their food I tried this time to have lunch and also i love it do much

photos.caption: Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom

TiSmJS5GE09pDEaiQuqmdA.text: This was my second time coming - the food is amazing - definitely get the burrata - the mustard seeds on top complement it so well. Another favorite is the polenta truffle chips, although they are quite rich! The service isn't hugely amazing, the waiters felt a bit absentminded, but maybe it's the Sunday mood. Finally, i highly recommend to put in your reservation not to sit downstairs - the atmosphere is not as relaxing down there, and I don't think it's worth it. Ps, bring your phone to the bathroom! Best bathroom hehe :)

Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. The butternut squash
Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. the amazing burrata

7teb_dSv157Grgx0tIxgyg.text: Great restaurant and not overly pretentious.  I really enjoyed NOPI, though I wouldn't classify it as one of my top-10 meals ever (as some of my friends had said).  Before getting to the food, some things I liked were the service and atmosphere.  The service was not at all stuffy and quite helpful.  In fact, I was about to try a bottle of "orange wine" and the waitress was very concerned because I had not tried it before.  She ended up encouraging us to try it first and after we did went with a more traditional red, she saved us from a bad wine experience.  The ambience was also neat and modern without being too faux trendy, which is what you often get in London.My friend and I had a collection of small plates, which ranged from good to great.  The burrata with blood orange and honey was great, ample portion of burrata and the blood orange complimented it well.  The courgette and manouri fritters were good but not as awesome as they sounded, tasted like deep fried fritters.  The cuttlefish was very good.  Sea Bream with rasam and potatoes also very good with a nice texture.  Possibly my favorite dish was twice cooked baby chicken, which we almost did not order.  The pork belly was also fantastic, with crackling done perfectly.  Finally, the venison, which was served in a pastry shell, was very good but not as classic as the other two meat dished.

OVq3p-WiIowwMszv3KXrNA.text: Delicious Mediterranean food with a creative twist. It's an elegant spot for lunch without being ridiculously expensive. There are plenty of vegetarian options, but all the meat-eaters agreed that the burrata with peaches was the star. Desserts are also excellent so save room - the peanut butter ice cream with house fudge sauce was as decadent as it sounds. Probably best to book a table.

JwAdIyhOoaxjyGlcQmuiGA.text: Been in London a while and this was my favorite meal here by far. The atmosphere was great, casual but nice, with spaced out tables so you were not on top of anyone else. Service was very good, not unbelievable, but completely solid. And the food, wow. The only thing I did not like was the squid, and they were fine, while everything else blew us away. The pork belly and the rabbit were both excellent. The pumpkin was a really nice surprise. Do I wish each dish was a couple pounds less? Of course. But you get what you pay for, and this was a really great meal. Will definitely return.

gFTXbb9lVSvixZIA5d4oaA.text: super creative menu (ie: not random ingredients put together to seem interesting but really tastes bad) & VERY tasty dishes. not REALLY small plates (they recommend 3pp but I'd say 2 suffice). LOVED the octopus (extremely soft!), smoked eggplant/aubergine w/pomegranite, and the miso quail was cooked to perfection. and the bathroom was unreal. like donald trump's

HtFJLeEWcuE9NL-Xgtw3Ew.text: I have had one of the most interesting breakfasts here; black rice with coconut milk and fruits. Next time; I will definitely try other items. Superb.

y_z5G2HYKy_n3aKi9OMICA.text: Food you would expect from Ottolenghi and a wonderful dinning experience. We went as a party of 3 and sat downstairs at the big shared tables. The staff really took great care to look after us. Friendly and relaxed with finness. We started with a Riesling from Slovenia. Fresh and flora if slightly one dimensional. They have a interesting wine list. We ordered 3 vegetable dishes and 3 fish. All with clean tastes and interesting mixes. They are tapas in size. We all had the cardinium rice pudding with an glorious raisin cake of a desert wine. Heaven. A bit pricey. Came to £50 per head but such a great evening. As the waiter kept saying 'enjoy!'

EHc_t5No4srtyp4nbToR-w.text: NOPI is the new venture of Yotam Ottolenghi, founder of London's highly successful gourmet deli/cafe chain "Ottolenghi". As a huge fan of deli, his columns in the Guardian newspaper, along with the recipes from his best-selling cookbooks, I had very high expectations of NOPI. Upon arrival, it was fairly obvious that much thought had been invested into the minor details of the restaurant. The golden "O" in the NOPI logo appeared to be a re-occurring theme throughout; from the coat tags given out at the front reception, the brass coloured vase, the shiny brass bar area at the back, right down to the napkin rings gave the restaurant a very stylish feel. And it was great to see the good man himself sat at the bar with friends ensuring that the cogs in the restaurant were running smoothly too! As with all the "hot tables" sweeping across London, with the likes of Bocca di Lupo, Polpo and Polpetto, the dishes are designed for sharing and it is recommended that you order three dishes per person. Our table of four ordered 9 savoury dishes and 2 desserts between us. Highlights was definitely the seared prawns with feta. This was a surprise winner given we weren't too sure about the combination to begin with, and without a doubt on the dessert front...the Pineapple gallette! You wouldn't have guessed that I'm not a huge fruit dessert fan as I launched into the thing - clearly eating beyond my quarter ration and practically licking the plate :) The bill came to about £40 per head including a cocktail per person. Admittedly with a couple of mixed reviews warning that prices were steep (£10 average per plate) and not to expect Ottolenghi's usual fare cuisine wise, I was a little bit apprehensive. But after our dining experience, I thought the meal was well worth the money based on NOPI's ethos of food quality, freshness and general gorgeousness. For full review and pics, please go to our blog: gourmetbelly.wordpress.c…  x

EecCws5sj_ggYfoLgDoQUg.text: i will never skip dessert here again.  i came back for dinner on fri, and 4 of us got 4 desserts (i know, we were piggies).  we justified this by ordering only 2 savories per person rather than the recommended 3 per person.  ;)i got the lime curd w/ mango, tapioca and meringue, and i was licking the bowl.  the coffee financiers w/ maple cream were divine.  the chocolate and peanut butter ice cream sundae was decadent, and the figs w/ honey and vanilla ice cream was just downright tasty.  i love this place so much, but i just wish i didn't smell like food after i finished eating (we were sitting downstairs this time).

eNRSC5n9aRjnMcPUD_AvVQ.text: Been a couple of times and enjoyed every dish we've had. First time was for a quick bite before a party in Soho and second for a long lingering meal with friends. Both times we were looked after brilliantly by the staff who appeared genuinely concerned and delighted that we were enjoying the food and wine. It is expensive - but where isnt in the area for genuinely top notch food? I will be back and will visit to impress or delight friends/colleagues.

YVYdT18mIhJ70davN-38Lg.text: Amazing food. If you like Ottolenghi, then you'll love NOPI. It's not cheap though, so save it for a special night out. Every combination of food we tried was outstanding. I'm slightly bummed there were only 2 of us so I couldn't try more food. yum!

xBQ1QeQLQsNeKPl2hgX6rw.text: Amazing restaurant.  The best food I have ever had in London.  Amazing wine list and the food is NOT your typical London faire

pbHa6sEpXYPkuJqbtPBsGw.text: I am a big big fan of the Ottolenghi flagship and the whole style of Yotam Ottolenghi's cooking and creativity, so no surprise that I love NOPI as well.  You book for either upstairs or downstairs.  The upstairs space is beautiful--white tiles, copper lamps, lots of space between you and your neighbor.  The downstairs looks awesome (I am a big fan of open kitchens and communal tables, and those are the two features of the downstairs.)  I'll book downstairs from now on, but if you want a more intimate upscale dinner book for upstairs.Loved the flavor explosions and interesting combinations.  The burrata was divine (who would have thought to put toasted coriander seeds on burrata?!?!)  The lamb was cooked to perfection, the octopus was exploding with flavors.  I must say I was a bit disappointed with dessert--the salted peanut ice cream thing didn't rock my world, and while the coffee financiers with maple cream were well-executed, I think I wanted a bit more from dessert.The service was a bit spotty (the food was coming in droves before she showed up with the bottle of wine).  But all in all, an excellent meal!

0fI0bvfJit7qRu5yZyTifQ.text: Absolutely fantastic dining experience! Booked the reservation online, no problems at all. Chose to sit downstairs with the view of the open kitchen. The seating here is two large communal tables, but the spacing is such that you feel like you really have your own space. The space is warm, and you feel a bit like you are sitting in the pantry as you are right next to shelves filled with scrumptious looking ingredients.I tried a couple of the cocktails, and was quite pleased. Interesting blends of juices and spirits, and a good range of flavours. Very easy to pair one cocktail with food and another with dessert.The waitstaff were really great! Answered all of our questions, and even brought us a sample of one of the components of a dish so we could taste a little bit before deciding what to order. Plus, bonus points for someone asking if it was okay to take away my cocktail (I really hate it when you are nursing that one last sip in the bottom of the glass and some pushy busperson whisks it away before you can protest).There was not a single dish that we tried that was not fantastic. Brilliant vegetarian options, and really good seafood (I don't eat meat so can't comment on that part of the menu). I remember incredible lemon curd, gorgeous asparagus (something I don't generally jump at ordering), scallops, etc. Then there was dessert. I highly recommend the lime and tapioca.I am looking forward to dining here again soon!

FYuZIs_xKletUBvdpOGmBg.text: Very good food. Great for an off-hours meal after shopping central London. Grilled aubergine and octopus small plates circa June 2014 very good. Courgette fritters so so.

rJAxATBobflbQlVJs6WNRw.text: Yotam Ottolenghi's posh restaurant offers stunningly inventive and flavourful food but with a few drawbacksOK, so first, and most importantly, the food. The shortish menu's divvied up into tasting plates that can also serve as starters, and a few mains. So you can order a la carte classic or a bunch of tapas-like small plates to share. Each plate we tried (nb: we're veggie) was superbly balanced, beautifully constructed and managed that stunning balancing act of both wacking great flavours that smack you round the mouth, but simultaneously delicate, intricate and subtle interplay between ingredients. That Ottolenghi's a smart chef  and he shows it off to great effect here. Plus, ingredients are super-fresh and tasty.That's how he can charge such high prices, basically. Yup, look at the menu and (if you're an average bloke like me), suck your breath in and start making calculations about whether you can afford two bottles of wine and pudding. For me, it's a special occasion meal price  but apparently not for most of the clientele. Which is drawback #2.Yup, Yuppies live! (it would seem). Expense account businessmen and newly-minted web developers on a coke binge dining their PRs seemed to be the order of the night on the Thursday we went. The conversation was loud on a few tables, the dresses very showy, and there was a lot of flashy ordering of expensive booze and cocktails. Don't these people know we're in the middle of a recession? And can they not keep down the boasts about their sexual performance just a tad while I'm trying to eat?!To go with the high-end prices and high-scale customer/idiots there is also slightly intrusive waiting. It's one of those places where someone tops up your wine the moment you're down to half a glass. That said, our sommelier was good at combining wine knowledge with witty banter  and struck the right note with us, which for him obviously meant a slight shift in tone from the usual clientele.Finally, decor, is bizarre. The upstairs is a tad too stark  white tile walls bounce the (aforementioned braying) sound about too much. But the real star is the toilets  like the Sultan Of Brunei's WC, only I'm guessing even more gaudy  with ludicrous mirrors everywhere.All that said, I bring you back to the start and the food  it's absolutely brilliant. And for the odd flash meal out, that trumps all other concerns.

6kWd4ec4EO6lE_DT46Ud3g.text: NOPI is another tapas / sharing plate restaurant but the quality of the food was just amazing.  I'd have to say that every dish was delicious but the three that stood out for me were the braised pigs cheek with cream corn, the black figs with goat cheese and candied walnuts and finally the mango kafir meringue desert.  The décor was elegant and they also had an affordable wine list.  This is one of the best restaurants I've been to in a while.

TXOvfVz3iB20bga8fRQrlg.text: What a great find on Yelp, this was delightful and had a variety of amazing Vegetarian friendly tapas that were all well crafted and delicious. Good wine selection as well. Do make reservations in advance.

USCmQba0wWjY5mU0GYoDfw.text: Interesting twist on food.  Portions wee small, and overpriced in my opinion.  Service was great.

4m79_mAj6LGqjGCR3QMehw.text: Exceptionally delicious food.Like Ottolenghi but even more refined and exotic in the flavour combinations.The most delicious broccoli (chargrilled) and mashed potato (lots of roasted garlic, lemon and olive oil)  I have ever eaten; fat scallops with a slightly overpowering relish; moist baby chicken with fabulous seasoning; miso quail with grapes which 'tasted like Christmas' according to my husband; and soft figs with perfect goat's cheese, caramelised walnuts and huge blackberries.  Tiny portions (you need at least 3 plates as a main course, if not four).Great staff who know what they are serving, have tasted it, and can answer questions sensibly.We ate a late lunch so the noise level was a pleasant hubbub but with lots of flat, hard surfaces I imagine it gets very noisy when full.Very expensive.

KzPvTPnN-Ykmu1dB0L-l_w.text: Lovely room, great atmosphere, friendly service and delicious food with some interesting flavour combinations. Would have got 5 stars but for the fact it's sharing plates!

TYRfcAj1PDC55tDnxFwPtg.text: If you are looking for a sexy London restaurant, this is it - the decor is gorgeous and the bathrooms are justifiably famous.  But it's not all looks and no substance.  If it were in a dilapidated warehouse I would still love it because the food is outrageously good.  Their savory cheesecake is one of those dishes you remember years later.  The cocktails are inventive and potent.  The service is attentive but never intrusive.  In short, damn near close to perfection.

VZrmheGACReye8_RjbQLig.text: Nopi is one of the few places where it doesn't really matter what you decide to order. I have been to plenty of great restaurants in which I found the food good, but I didn't like everything... and honestly, that is to be expected as everyone has specific tastes. I went to Nopi with a group of 5 and we split about 15 of the dishes with the thought we would re-order our favorites afterwards. When we got to the end of the meal, everyone was stuffed (definitely larger than tapas) and no one could agree on one dish that was better than the others! We agreed that it was just necessary to come back. Honestly, the prices definitely reflect the quality and if its too expensive for you, I'm sure Nopi will survive as there is quite a waiting list. We booked 2 weeks in advance for a Saturday night and barely made it in off the waiting list (mostly thanks to my girlfriends persistance on the phone). My advice: Go with a group. This is a seriously deep menu and believe me you'll want to taste as much of it as possible! Standouts for me were the Aubergine tart, broccolini, and the cheesecake (not a dessert, if you can believe it).

PkXJgCt3vgaUEKjo2QFBFg.text: delightful. we're going back and have booked already :) my fish was too spicy, but that seems more choice-oriented. we enjoyed the rest of the food and the vibe.

V6Xzul1BOOfGIQOI4QX7cA.text: I am just about getting over my fullness enough so that I can sit up and type. I have had the lucky privilege of going to today, Ottolenghi's new restaurant venture. If you're not in the know, Ottolenghi is a set of food shops/cafes in London that focus on fresh punchy ingredients, full of bright and bold flavors. I've been a fan for a while and often dabble in recipes from their older cookbook and when I spotted on twitter that they were doing a soft opening for Nopi at 50% off, I jumped at the chance and booked a table for me and my boyfriend's family. Nopi itself is absolutely stunning. Tucked just behind bustling Regent Street the restaurant is housed in a beautiful two floored building; the ground floor which you enter on is decorated almost entirely in bold white marble and glittering golden brass, so that any colour in the furniture and food really pops out at you, overall the feel of the place is sleek, formal and bright. Downstairs the basement is setup in a canteen style with delicious store cupboard products on display and a view straight into the kitchen making the space feel warm and more casual. On walking in, I was faced with a beautiful ornate gold lampshade, a bowl of overflowing, brash red chillis and a view to the back of the restaurant where I could see smiling staff bustling around tables of diners sharing food. Immediately, our coats were taken, we were shown to our table smack bang in the middle of the restaurant and handed paper dated menus. The menu varied slightly to the one shown online, but it was exciting, assorted and easy to read. Even though we were clearly somewhere very special and a bit posh, there was no menu intimidation; dishes were split into 'meat', 'fish' and 'veg' and there was no offputting language, cooking techniques or ingredients I hadn't heard of. We all took Ottolenghi's advice and went for what seems to be their unique selling point; grab three savory dishes each and share the whole lot with everyone round the table. There was plenty of umming and ahhing about having two and a half each so as not to over-order, but logistics and excitement at the delectable menu got the better of us and before we knew it we were all declaring our choices so as not to miss out on anything. Food started arriving within about 15 minutes, and once it did, it didn't seem to stop. Our dishes came out at different times, not when they were ready in the kitchen, but more as the staff saw fit. Food came grouped into complimenting formats, with ingredients and flavours that seemed to match. They arrived about three at a time which meant we had time to really oogle over and appreciate each one. I won't go through each and every dish, but want to show you some of the ones that really stood out as a unique culinary experiences. Some of them were like nothing else I have ever eatean, which is an impressive declaration for such tiny dishes. The beef brisket croquets were incredible and appreciated by all. They were crunchy and crisp on the outside and were filled with pulled beef that oozed with salty, rich juices when you sliced into them. They were cut through by the Asian Slaw which was light, citrusy and fresh. The lamb meatballs were a complete triumph. The lamb was pink and tender and rolled with crunchy pine-nuts and topped with surprise smoked aubergine that tasted of bbqs and bonfires. The yoghurt sauce was creamy, nutty and moreish and the pomegranate was so light and fresh that it made me feel like I wasn't eating anything too naughty.. Then the Ossobuco with polenta arrived, I admit I've never cooked with polenta so have no idea if anyone and everyone can get the stuff tasting that good, but my oh my, it turned out to be my favourite dish. It was smeared onto the plate like a squashed pancake, was deliciously cheesy and smooth and paired perfectly with the soft, flaked ossobuco (veal shanks braised in white wine, vegetables and thier broth). If you take any of my recommendations to heart make sure it's this one. The vege dishes were just as fabulous, the cheesey, sweet and creamy fondant swede gratin a particular favourite thanks to its contrasting textures of soft swede and crunchy cabbage (and not only because it came in a lovely individual pot). The winter greens were rich and juicy yet retained a crunchy bite and the baked cheesecake? Well that lasted only seconds, it was literally eaten so quickly that I couldn't get a photo! The blu di pecora, which is a blue veined sheeps cheese, was balanced with sweet leaks and baked until it was light and almost quiche like. Burrata is a type of mozzarella that from the outside mimics an ordinary mozarella completely, but on the inside is a mix of the stringy cheese as we know and love it and rich delicious cream. As we chopped through it sourish white liquid spilt out and mingled delciously with the sweet, sharp blood orange segments and the fragrant coriander seeds. The green beans sadly never materialised

2FNxN0SyajPKVqA5fvP1Rg.text: Dinner for 2 on a Saturday evening. NOPI has the usual tables on the ground floor, and 2 large canteen-style tables overlooking the kitchen downstairs which had a more casual feel. We preferred a table upstairs. We had the burata, roasted cauliflower and mackerel as 'appetisers', and the double-cooked chicken (which tasted quite Asian and was served with ginger chilli sauce and salt), fried courgette flowers and 2 sides (quinoa and potatoes) for 'mains'. We could have done with one less side dish as there was too much food (note: we have big appetites!). We shared the financiers for dessert which wasn't as special as the other dishes. Our favourites were the burata, mackerel and chicken. Service was a bit disappointing though for a restaurant of this standard. Our waiter was very pleasant and friendly, but on 2 occasions cleared our plates even though we were just finishing our food, and took our napkin away before we ordered dessert. Although quite pricey, the food was really good and we will visit again.

BLb-6rdxFuXDo8K5vnk2pw.text: Great design...and the bathrooms are wortha visit! We went for a birthday lunch and the food was brilliant but the service a bit slow. Perhaps that's the relaxed attitude they are going for but seemed odd since they had put us on a time limit. I would definitely go back as there are other dishes I'm keen to try.

gEbbifshRDYFADNrwlFBlA.text: Going to NOPI was at the top of my list of things to do while visiting London and I was not disappointed at all! My husband and I enjoyed every dish we ordered (beetroot, green beans, burrata, courgette fritters, and dessert) and are excited to go home and try to recreate some in our own kitchen!As a vegetarian, it can be limiting to go to most restaurants and only be able to choose from a couple things on the menu, but at NOPI we had an abundance of options which was really exciting for us!The restaurant is just as beautiful as the food and the service was attentive and friendly. Will definitely be back!

Df_hQtWQ9Xpsu96hm_FPfw.text: Interesting dishes. I own Otto Lenghi's Plenty cookbook so was great to go to one of his actual restaurants and try his food! Everything I tried was super inventive and interesting and I like how he uses different not so familiar spices and flavors. I ordered a couple small plates and a main entree thinking that a small vegetable dish like "eggplant" was not gonna leave me satisfied but because there's lots of flavors being used I actually got full rather quickly.  I also had the goat which was quite nice (also it was as completely boneless which is nice) and a cabbage dish with dried shrimp that was also quite interesting. Open, modern and culinary ambience. Waiter was helpful in us trying to make a decision.

photos.caption: Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom

kKU-r6dBnX7jwWYdlgD4XQ.text: There are a few times when you look at yelp for suggestions in a foreign country and you find the very best restaurant that fits all your wants and needs. This place was superb! We made reservations on our one night short stopover in London and this place didn't disappoint. The entrees are not very big so this is a place you get a few things and share. The drinks were excellent with an extensive wine list. Can't wait to come back here next time I'm in London!

4WluJus5KwkeBlL42wmrCw.text: The restaurant had a nice feel, cozy and contemporary. There is also a downstairs area with two chef's-style tables next to an open kitchen, which I assume are for private reservations. The waitstaff were very pleasant and attentive.We ordered the Shakshuka w/ braised eggs and smoked labneh and the corn & polenta cakes with fried egg and avocado salsa. Both dishes were cooked brilliantly and the freshness of the ingredients shined through. Having had a fair share of shakshukas, this one ranks high with the addition of smoked labneh that brings a great flavor punch to the large tomato and golden egg combo. The toast with slightly burnt edges adds a nice depth.The corn cakes were also well balanced with great textures from the whole sweet corn mixed into the cake and the avocado salsa brings a nice creamy, citrus finish. Combine it all together with the mixed greens and the flavor profile was worth the visit!

31tqOBrYJiVYAfcEjI-_Pg.text: On vacation in London, I used Yelp religiously to find great restaurants for my family and me to try out. We love Mediterranean food, so when I came upon NOPI, with its nice photos, rave reviews, and the menu, we quickly made a reservation. Located in SoHo just steps from Regent St and Piccadilly Circus, NOPI is on a quiet street away from the hustle and bustle yet close enough to be convenient to walk to. When we arrived for our reservation at NOPI, the hostesses were so sweet and hung up our coats and and umbrellas (free of charge) before leading us to our table. On the main level, the space at NOPI is long and narrow with a small alcove in the front and a full bar in the back. As you can see from many of the pictures, NOPI is a bright space with lots of white and gold accents. Downstairs is the kitchen with a large communal table, perfect for private parties and large groups. The tables upstairs are suitable for small groups of 2-6 people. There's bar seating as well.The menu has many options, including dishes to share, and it caters well to vegetarians. My party and I started our meal with a few dishes to share: butternut squash and the sea bream. Both were absolutely delicious -- I highly recommend! For our main dishes, I had the duck leg confit while the other two in my party both had the chickpea pancake. We enjoyed all of our dishes. The duck was falling off the bone, and it was perfectly paired with a crisp, fresh coconut salad. We had two side dishes to share as well: brussels sprouts and the kale, apple, and turnip salad. We enjoyed our entire meal! For dessert, we had the blackcurrant sorbet and the roasted pineapple with coconut ice cream and macadamia nuts. Both were excellent, and I particularly liked the simple roasted pineapple that was warm and naturally sweet.We thoroughly enjoyed our experience at NOPI from the ambience and the food presentation to the food itself and the service from the hostesses and waitstaff. This is definitely a top restaurant on our list whenever we plan to visit London again!
