leeOBSoUAKKQnmSxrtLamg.text: Green beans, coconut sambal, cucumber, pumpkin seeds: (2 stars) Sea bream, tamarind rasam, curried potato: (3 stars) cooked well but little flavorSpiced potato cake, tamarind, pine nut yoghurt: (1 stars) zero tasteOttolenghi roasted spiced nuts: (5 starts) great flavorsNOTE: Extremely tiny portions, very little flavor, and very high prices for quality of food

v6OwUArupePFqo6gYmReNA.text: Nopi was great even during a quiet lunch service. Downstairs was a welcome escape from the heat and loved seeing all the ingredients near the communal tables. The blue cheesecake shuffle with beets and toasted almonds is definitely worth the hype.  Transcendtal.  I really liked the crispy-skinned roasted lemon myrtle chicken with chilli, lime and salt and also the chickpea pancake with spice peas, tomato and a nice punch of yuzu.And then they surprised us with a happy birthday green melon sorbet with vodka :) Bravo!

RxIPXrYPd_tsbJxxKj_cow.text: Excellent as usual. Fantastic brunch of high quality food. Similar menu to his other locations, but more high-end in terms of decor and service. Although I normally get the Shakshuka this time I tried the Tofu Scramble based on our servers recommendation to change things up. It was good, but nothing like the Shakshuka :)

LwG0Ceg0oAdkftQomBP9mQ.text: Great food. We went there for Brunch on Sunday and were not disappointed. Highlights included the sea bream and the Cumbarian pork belly. We were not disappointed. Great place would recommend, however beware to book ahead !

bVcdAfHLEUdgXEyMckmXIw.text: The food was good. The service RUINED IT! Upon ordering they told us when we had to vacate the table. Then they came back shortly before the "deadline" and said we could take another 15 minutes! Now we had a longstanding reservation. We were not seated as a favor. It was rush rush rush like I've never experienced before. What is the point of having a nice meal if you are under pressure to order and leave? I felt like I was the piece of meat. Shameful is the only way to describe it.

Nc-hwonA_VVGOELuD8UgTw.text: I was so disappointed!!!! Came here with a friend and we were looking forward to the meal, being big Ottelenghi fans. Meal was one-noted, FLAVORLESS ! And served luke-warm! An awful sweet flavor was cast over entire meal -- no use of citrus or acid. Chicken entree was BONE DRY and slathered in a sweet sauce. Other items, which our waitress sung the praises of, where beyond unremarkable. You know a meal is bad when you can't even be bothered to stay & try dessert !!!!

0FACgBZWBGhnrL8c00EM6w.text: Love love loved this place. Went here back in January 2017 in London with my boyfriend for one of our date nights. I made a reservation the day of on a Thursday night for 6PM online without a problem. I heard of this restaurant because a friend in New York had Ottolenghi's cookbook and cooked something for us. I loved what she cooked so had to try the restaurant in London. Best decision ever! We ordered 1 main dish and a few sides. The main was the confit duck leg and the sides were the twice-cooked baby chicken, Valdeon cheesecake, and the venison w/ peanuts & blackberries. The cheesecake was by far my favourite dish. I could have eaten a whole one for myself!! All of the dishes were bursting in flavour! The venison was incredible! There was a perfect balance of flavours with the sauce, the peanuts, and blackberries. The lemon myrtle salt with the also made the dish wonderful. Lastly, the duck was also just the perfect way to end the meal. We were too stuffed to get dessert! The service was great! The atmosphere was wonderful as well. I would highly recommend this and would definitely return again!

photos.caption: Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Twice-cooked baby chicken
Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Valdeon cheesecake - AMAZING!!!!!!!
Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Confit duck leg

i5ZpAgR4y476fVUSxOKefA.text: Oh no, NOPI!! We were sooooo excited for a visit to NOPI. I have cooked from each of the Ottolenghi cookbooks extensively and just love the food. It is always so surprising how well certain combinations work, how easy it is to prepare a wonderful feast with a healthy array of great ingredients. In this case, I think we may just have picked the wrong restaurant to visit.If you are looking for the flagship Ottolenghi experience, it is my sense that this one just isn't it. If like me you looked at the menu online and thought: oh, full bar with extensive cocktail list, puddings menu, etc. this must be the one, it just isn't. Most of the dishes are cold preparations or really simply prepared meals without the pizzazz of the Ottolenghi touch.  We were so disappointed by the menu altogether, and afterwards, as we lamented our culinary downer in our hotel, we looked again at the other menus. The Spitalfields location appears to be the one doing the larger, more interesting composed dishes. Take a look at that menu - I think we would have been happier had we gone there. To be frank, dishes like the jicama were really just jicama and salsa on a plate. Not even artfully presented. The burrata was nice, but the accompaniments were too simple to be anything particularly revelatory; the other location seems to present it more artfully. We were told that dishes like the polenta chips were very rich. They weren't. They were just chips with a mayonnaise on the side. Again, nothing artful about it.Our poor server was running around like mad: they need FAR more staff here not to make this a slow experience. She was a whirling dervish and did a great job keeping up, but when you are paying $200 for very basic small plates, you shouldn't have to admire the stamina of your server.Cocktails were nice. Desserts were so very humdrum that we didn't even bother.So, in sum, go to one of the bakeries for breakfast or look at the Spitalfields location for Ottolenghi love if you are in London.  This one seemed to be an elevated version, but alas, it really fell flat.

hxfdpPBqNbGyHA1BU6Gxzw.text: This place is fabulous and a must try in London. Good atmosphere, which was heightened from the start with some excellent custom cocktails. Their Penicillin is the real deal. We then just split a bunch of small plates, each of which was delicious. Started with the Burata coated with cardamom seeds that not only added flavor but a nice contrast in texture. The roasted Auvergne was amazing; the mix of flavors just washed over your palette in a cascade of flavors. The polenta fries were also incredible and perfectly cooked. The kale had a nice spicy zest which was the perfect foil to the fries. The final small plate  was the venison, which was the single best preparation of the dish I have ever had. All washed down with an excellent Sicilian red that had that characteristic  noise associated with the Mount Edo volcanic soil.In short, of of my best dining experiences in London.

q0DjI-w8kC4qIQjKczvTsA.text: I've heard a lot of buzz about this restaurant and was so excited to finally try it. As a party of 4 for lunch, we were a bit early for our reservation and was able to be seated. Nice plus for a very hard to get reservations for dining upstairs!The dining room is sleek, white, and modern. It's a very comfortable dining area. My reason for knocking off a star is because of our service that we had received. Our server seemed a bit put off because we were not ordering any cocktails with our lunch. Prejudging by a server can lead to a not so great dining experience, my friends and I love to eat, also being a restaurant owner I tend to see a bit more than other customers do. A separate check request was given a disapproving attitude. After that we had to request more olive oil for our bread, more still water, dessert from another server and our food bill.The food was outstanding! The valdeón cheesecake, crispy potatoes with truffle oil, and pork chop with Spring vegetables. No complaints about the quality of food.I wish we had a better service experience to make me want to return on my next visit to London, but there's too many other great restaurants to try.My friends were here the day before almost ordering the same items they ate the time before. That tells me how much they enjoyed the food, they actually complained about the service to management. Too bad- we would've ordered dessert.

photos.caption: Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Pork chop with spring vegetable.
Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Crispy potatoes- a must try.
Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Valdeon cheesecake. Yum!

6PZy6zmWA318yHH0ISKaTA.text: Decently priced and amazing food! Loved the mozzarella cheese and blood orange, and their twice cooked chicken! Cocktails may not be the best though... But amazing service too!

photos.caption: Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Mozzarella cheese and blood orange

L7bK8hXfZp0bjXE_6ZMWOg.text: Delicious brunch while in London. We ordered the shakshuka and the corn and polenta fritters. Both had a good depth of flavor and seasoned very lightly. I ended up adding some additional salt and pepper and was very pleased with both dishes. Nice light meal to start the day that didn't leave me feeling to full.

photos.caption: Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom
Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom
Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom

0LPIjYtd56DluFudqIdHhQ.text: We had a nice, but not outstanding, experience at Nopi. The restaurant itself is gorgeous - the design and the vibe is very elegant and feels special, without being ostentatious or pretentious.There is a sizable and creative cocktail menu, so we started with a couple of cocktails, along with the truffle polenta chips. The cocktails were excellent, and the polenta chips, which come with a very subtle garlic aioli, are outstanding. I kind of wish we had ordered more of them.There is a section of the menu called "Mains", but instead we opted for a handful of small plates. I initially thought we'd need 7-8 small plates to make a meal, but our waiter guided us to a smaller number (maybe five or six), and I'm very grateful for it. We did find room for dessert, but we were extremely satisfied after that number of plates.The standout dishes for us were the lavosh with burnt spring onion dip, the roast aubergine with yoghurt and pickled lemon, the cheesecake with pickled beets and almonds. I ordered the pork belly with pepper chutney, and when I tried cutting into it, it was pretty dry and tough (hard to cut through with a knife). I asked the waiter if that was expected, and he said "no, definitely not" and whisked it off the table. A manager came to the table next to apologize, but explained that all of the pork belly dishes came from the same piece of pork belly, so they would all be the same, and he suggested I order something different. On one hand, I felt like this was a fair way to handle the situation, but on the other hand felt a little bit like it was my fault, as if I was a customer who would never be pleased. I ordered the mackerel instead, which was fine.For dessert we had the apple ginger bread trifle and the coffee and pecan financiers. The financiers were amazing. They come with a maple cream that I am currently installing a dispenser for in my kitchen. I'm kidding, but it is delicious.I'm a little soured on the pork belly situation (which would be a good name for a band), but hope to be back again to try again.

photos.caption: Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Storefront on Warwick St.

LFmeg-Eo3zHeclZpcEa7Cg.text: This is a nice buzzy place Good atmospherePortions way too small though  . We all had a starter and shared . burrada was good rest were tasty but  mostly vegetarian basedSweetbreads were ruined in a deep fryerI had a great but minuscule halibut with a grilled but tasteless Bok Choi It's not cheap five people starter main tap water one carafe of wine and three coffees one dessert  300 pound check They also add service charge  service is average Someone takes your order and is hard to hail but nice and polite  and someone else brings your foodThe first thing my wife and I did ( four hours after we sat down at restaurant ) when we returned home was make a burger  as we were starvingSo food was tasty and unique but if you are hungry and in search of more protein based food ( except fried chicken)  then I would pick somewhere elseIf you are dating a vegetarian then it's a great spot

g8i_0VY_aqzE952gt2BpVA.text: Very nice lunch spot.  We were a party of six.  Everyone enjoyed their meal from simple dishes like salads to the more complex.  This is farm to table.  Service was fine.  The restaurant gets crowded so book in advance.

bFavt4HVz7J53CBc12jUmQ.text: I really recommend this place. We ordered lots of small plates to begin with and everything was really good. All the dishes had a lot of flavor and there were definitely unexpected food combinations but everything was great. I had the duck and enjoyed it. Good wine. Cozy atmosphere and friendly staff.

LOtdf2xmZ_BWGbujrLTU0Q.text: Ate there twice during trip in September for breakfast.  It was delicious both times.  Shakshuka with smoked Labaneh? Novel, but more importantly, extremely tasty combo, served in the pan, just like in Israel.  White bean stew was bursting with flavor, I could taste the cardamom, which was a nice touch.  Eggs were velvety.  Got a slab of bacon, not just little bits.  Walked out full, and contented with unique takes on Israeli food.  Usually high end places don't cut it for me.  They are usually too refined and lack the soul of home cooking and smaller establishments.  This place was the exception.  I almost forgot to mention, that there were some unique fresh made juices as well that should not be missed.The decor in this place is insanely over the top.  Kind of like Jerusalem stone on steroids.  Reminds me of a museum.  Bathrooms look like they came out of the House of Saddam.  I am not complaining.  Despite the ostentatious appearance, and the fact you pass the subterranean kitchen on the way to the toilets, for some inexplicable reason, it works.  Last note-the manager did not charge us for drinks- and we drank a lot- when he heard that we had to wait a little longer for our food with two hungry children in our party who where under four years old.  Classy move.  Great food, great neighborhood- Soho, good service.  Yotam Ottolenghi really does a great service to  the burgeoning Israeli cuisine scene.

GklZjyG_bkQrdI9Rgp0cTQ.text: Fantastic!  Everything we had was amazing. Chickpeas, beetroot, chicken. The duck is a can't miss. Very cool atmosphere. Bartenders are really good. Overall a superb experience. Don't miss it!!

ZNMOexEtT16867eYMF8vOA.text: There are places in London that try to be American (specifically NYC). Most fail miserably. I'm pretty sure NOPI isn't trying to be as Upper East Side Manhattan, but it really, really is. I walked in for lunch yesterday and could have sworn I was sitting somewhere between Madison and Park in the upper 70's. The space is done in all-white subway tiles and with brass deco fixtures. Very New York. The service? Also very New York. Without prompting, we were presented with a bottle of tap water. Our glasses were refilled again and again by the attentive--but not in an annoying way--staff. The clientele? Very "Ladies Who Lunch." At 1:30 the place was pretty much full. I counted only three male diners. The food? Well, this was kind of the downfall. It's not cheap by any means. The small plate (meant for sharing, of course) entrees run between 9 and 12GBP a plate. We had five dishes, dessert, two glasses of wine, and coffee, and it came to just under 80GBP. Most everything was underseasoned, and there were a couple odd combinations. We tried the lamb meatballs, beef brisket croquettes, a cured white fish (hake maybe?), the seared scallops, and the baked blue cheese cheesecake. The lamb meatballs were served in a yogurt-based sauced that reminded me of a stroganoff... and then they topped it with pomegranate. Outside of needing salt, and the addition of the pomegranate seeds, the dish was not bad. The cured fish also fell into this category, as did the scallops. The standouts were the croquettes with a side of Asian slaw that was really lovely. I also liked the cheesecake, although it was more of a quiche, than a cheesecake. However, it was tasty with its side of mushrooms. For dessert we had the Sultana financiers, which were good, but nothing special. The barista came to check on our coffee, as they were training someone new, and she wanted to make sure it wasn't burnt. That was a nice touch for sure.Also beware of the toilets if you're claustrophobic. They've tried to counteract the size of the room by completely covering it in angled mirrors. What they really accomplished looks like it came straight out of Al Pacino's loo in Scarface. Break out the rolled twenty and the bag of... well, you know... Anyway, I can't say this is one of my favourite places for lunch. For the price, there are much better deals. However, I would imagine this would be a nice date spot in the evenings. The staff and the surroundings outshine many of the dishes at this point. Hopefully this will change over the next few months.

7Ftgzas4GpCtkEfs79eeBA.text: Nopi is a great restaurant. They offer a nice variety of healthy, vegan dishes in addition to other fare.  The place has a nice vibe during lunch. I'd highly recommend Nopi.

tQMIH4Ey4hsIkC8awbhAkQ.text: Food was A-MAZING!  I ended up buying the cookbook "Jerusalem"!  It's pricey but worth the experience.  The portions are not huge and best shared but the taste left me wanting to go back the next day!

updQv3uaxmvcmvF1eWnq1A.text: I was very excited to try NOPI and it did not disappoint! I loved the fresh, flavorful vegetable centric menu with lots of exciting flavors. We went with a large group that included some die hard meat and potatoes fans, and even they warmed up to much of the cuisine with the chicken and pork belly being favorites. My favorite outside of the vegetarian options was the octopus - outstanding.

osB7imknP7Wb36LJ9IGFjA.text: This place is unbelievably good - definitely a culinary highlight in London! You MUST go if you're interested in trying many delicious, fresh, incredible flavors with friends, or want to go on a romantic date with your significant other. We had a phenomenal, friendly server who took great care of us, and helped us pick all the right things on the menu. Everything tasted perfect.Simply unbeatable! I will be back next time I stop in London!

WJhPAJhwKhuLmJ-YmpcFow.text: Really delicious, delicate food from the Ottolenghi people. Little plates that are great for sharing, with truly unique food and flavor combinations. (*And even though it's not strictly vegetarian, it's a good choice for those who eat things like "vegetables" and "quinoa.")

RikKTesYHFQYC6HGdfeOhw.text: Came all the way from Chicago to host London friends.  Our  reservation  was for the downstairs, which has a communal table. It was 5:45. There was the table that seated 12 (I think). There were three of us who took our seats, two at the end and one alongside. The staff would not let us sit in that configuration because it's not "how they arrange their seating."  They want us to sit two alongside and one at the end in case another party came in. Well, there were three other corners .  I told the greeter that one of us is hard of hearing and we couldn't have a meal so far apart  or one of would not hear the conversation.   Did not matter. 'We asked nicely, we implored, then we got angry but they were adamant. You sit how we say you sit or you can't eat here. We left. I'm sure they didn't care one bit since the place is so hot, but they won't last if they treat customers like this, particularly when no one else was in the room or at the table. I'll eat Ottolenghi's food in my own kitchen, where I can seat guests where I like.

aQsD4R_40Bf2A3e67i3jCA.text: Nopi is a super unique, delish restaurant in the heart of Soho; its very hard to surprise my tasete buds and Nopi really stepped it up for me.  We came in and were greeted by a lovely hostess.  She took my coat and umbrella and promptly had us seated. This was a special birthday for my husband so I wanted to make sure everything went smoothly and it did.  We started off with a nice medium bodied bottle of French red wine and nibbled on this eggpant appetizer with pomegranate seeds and lavash , which was so delicious, the flavors came together so well.  There are options of getting mains or sharing a bunch of small plates.  We opted to do a tasting of small plates and ordered:Burrata with toasted coriander seeds and peach with honey.  I thought this was such a yummy and unique flavor.Figs with goat cheese and sweet potato- Ths was actually quite nice as well -- I probably would lean towards this rather than the burrata if I were forced to make a choice. Double cooked chicken-SOOO moist and delicious!  The flavors were awesome and even if you didnt eat the skin, you could taste the flavors, an indication to me that they really marinated the chicken.Roast sirloin- This was the only dish I wasnt in love with. It was served too rare for my taste but I also dont really eat beef so I'm not a good judge.  My husband thought it was fine but preferred the chicken.And of course to round out the evenign, we had some great dessert, which didnt sound super appetizing but was sooo good--peanut ice cream with toffee and chocolate.  heaven on a plate. No seriously.  We enjoyed that with a port, and ended our night a little heavier from the drinking and eatin but so much happier and fulfilled.   I would go here agian for a special occasion, but clearly this is not an every day eating establishment.

98XnXuEVYy7_BAdwRUFJUA.text: The restaurants of a celebrity chefs can be tricky. You usually pay a celebrity premium for mediocre food that doesn't resemble what you watch in TV or read in the newspapers. NOPI is an exception. Food is tasty and high quality and the restaurant is very nice. Yes the place is crowded because Ottolenghi is very well known. But if you forget about it and concentrate on the food, it is quite good. Unfortunately,  vegetarian options are limited in Nopi, although the ones offered are very good.

oBFsP4aapE3MXHcnMCmwWg.text: Second visit here, haven't been able to reserve upstairs at individual table but large shared tables downstairs fine. Not cheap but tasty well cooke dfood, starters to share or not! Not the cheapest place around but good service, good food.

1H8W77LBVa5SVIJbw8zfgg.text: What can I say? I actually thought this place was great. Maybe a bit on the pricey side, but it is central London and big-name chefs of Ottolenghi fame. Your savory dishes come in 3 categories: vegetables, fish, and meat. Those are three categories I like, so the menu suited me quite well.As part of a group with 6 people, we were able to try basically everything on the menu. Some real highlights of the evening were the cocktails (which I did not try), the greens with yogurt sauce, the pork cheeks, and the pomegranate with lamb. The menu changes very frequently, so you may have a totally different selection depending on when you go.I was too stuffed to try dessert, but apparently the chocolate ganache was amazing.Gluten-free notes: The menu changes daily. Ask them to take a menu into the kitchen and mark up what you can or can't eat. They were happy to do this. I was able to eat about half of the vegetable and meat dishes, all of the fish dishes, and about half of the desserts. Definitely didn't go hungry here!

lG7oZwfoPJcnjOIPNGcsng.text: Sheesh, London. Why you have to be so expensive??I've been spoiled by NYC. Never thought that would be the case.Anyway, the food was quite tasty but it's really like getting tapas. Small plates for double the price of a regular spot, then tack on the conversion rate. Ay mama!! Me and a friend split four plates and dessert and had a couple of drinks. My half was $72. Remember I said TAPAS which I split with my friend. Supposedly some big name chef who is quite meticulous in preparing the food. Nice to know there was lots of love put in the dishes and the price tag to follow.We sat downstairs at the communal table (not so much a fan) but it was a nice feel. The bathroom is crazy! You have to check it out. Mirrors everywhere!Also, if it's on the menu, you must try the financiers....SO GOOD.

_1nvaIvAY2I0QXx_By3hAw.text: Had a fun dinner there--great atmosphere.  We had the burrata, sirloin, chicken and pork tenderloin to share between 3 of us.  Small plates equals small portions, but very flavorful and filling.  We were told that they needed our table at 930 aka we weren't invited to linger.  Very good food though and a hip cool location/space.

PddZu9nH2gTLVSMAh3UF5w.text: I love it here. Have been twice for lunch and twice for dinner, which each time better than the last, as I felt more educated on how/what to order.  If you're a first timer, i'd recommend going with a non-first timer so they could take the lead on ordering.  It's mostly shared plates (not sure why anyone would want to committ to a main when there are so many good small plates!) so again, i'd recommend going with a group of 4 rather than just a couple, so you can order a bit of everything.  I looove the cheesecake dish, the buratta, the duck breast with watermelon, and basically anything on the menu. The room is gorgeous, and has a great natural light in the day due to a skylight. This is a place you can bring anyone - your mom, your grandma, and your trendy (or non trendy) friends. Not too quiet, not too loud, and just wouldn't be offensive to anybody.

mqOXmeP0hS50YTfUPGgLSg.text: For more and photos please visit my blog: hungryinlondon.com/2011/…  I usually miss new restaurant openings and go there about 2 years after everyone else. But not this time, mind you! There are two current bloggers' favourites, Spuntino (related to Polpo and Polpetto) and Ottolenghi's chic sister NOPI. Spuntino I'll probably visit in 2013, but Hooray! I have made it to NOPI and I am so glad I did. Most of you will know about the Israel-born Yotam Ottolenghi who has taken London by storm. We are talking bold combination of clean flavours taking its inspiration from Mediterranean cuisines with added influences from all around the world. These delicacies you can enjoy at (or rather take away from) Ottotlenghi joints in several locations all around London. But now the team behind Ottolenghi has transferred its philosphy and delicious cooking to a restaurant. NOPI (which apparently means North of Picadilly (??)) has just opened a couple of months ago in Warwick Street, a small side street just parallel to Regent's Street, and has seems to have won over even the toughest critics. (Independent, Guardian). When you enter Nopi the first thing you take in is the clean atmosphere  white tile walls, wooden furniture, brass lamps  and the smell of truffles. You know you have arrived at a good place. NOPI is all about sharing. Who knows me is aware that I really don't believe in the concept of 'your' or 'my' dish (sometimes not fully appreciated by my respective dinner companions who very selfishly want to enjoy what they have ordered all for themselves). NOPI is fully on my side here! In the menu it is stated that 3 savoury plates per person are recommended. You can choose from the 'vegetarian', 'meat' or 'fish' section of the pleasantly compact menu. We shared 5 dishes between us which was more than enough as the dishes were bigger than I had anticipated. The dessert was then eaten more out of curiosity than of need. The concept of NOPI's cooking seems easy  you take a good quality main ingredient and combine it with 3-4 flavours (different herbs, citrus fruits, chili) to make it into a unique and hugely pleasant culinary experience. Of the 6 dishes we ordered, 5 were superb and also the last one was, if not quite the level of the others, still far above average. I loved the Burrata, blood orange, coriander seeds (12). A luscious soft lump of mozzarella, silky on the outside and creamy within doesn't have much taste on its own. Combined with the roast coriander seeds generously sprinkled on top, the slices of blood orange and the small leaves of the spicy globe basil it resulted in a flavour and texture explosion. A little bit less dramatic but none the less enjoyable were the Braised carrots, mung beans, smoked labneh (10). The subtle flavour of the garden carrots worked lovely against the background of the mung beans (which very much tasted like lentils in my opinion) and the salty cheese gave just a little bit of kick to this otherwise mellow plate of food. We only went for one fish dish, Grilled hake kebabs, lemon pickle, yoghurt (10), and this was my least favourite. In fact when I tried the fish burger by itself I was really disappointed, it was dry and did not taste of much. But by then I had realised how NOPI works, so I loaded onto my fork a bit of fish cake, some of herbs (chervil, dill, and some various others), a slice of lime pickle and some of the sauce and suddenly, when the flavours came all together is my mouth, the dish went from one to three-dimensional. I loved loved loved the Roasted beef sirloin, baby fennel, pecorino (12) which was the source of the lingering truffle smell in the restaurant. Cold pieces of perfectly cooked beef were covered in thin slices of fennel (which reminds me again of how much I like fennel, I am surprised it is not used more often) and the supporting and not at all overpowering flavour of truffel oil. This is a must order dish. My dinner companion's favourite was the Twice-cooked baby chicken, kafir lime salt, chilli sauce (8). The chicken was superb. Beautifully tender in a thick sweet sauce it worked beautifully with the kafir lime salt. I was not keen on the chili sauce though, the chicken didn't need it in my opinion. Almost exploding at this stage the waiter was still able to persuade us to try the Cardamom rice pudding (6.5). I have a real weakness for rice pudding and this one just reinforced my opinion. More fluid than pudding consistency, this dessert combined the oriental flavours of cardamon and rose water with crunchy pieces of pistachio. Very scrumptious indeed. The service was efficient and amiable without being annoying and all the waiters were smiling a lot. If NOPI gives them a plate of their food once in a while I would be smiling too Now the downside NOPI is not cheap. None of the dishes costs more than 12 pounds but it adds up, particularly when you eat 3 dishes each. The wine menu

88wadMrla12dXaNTY25w1g.text: Good, but not great food.  This was recommended by several colleagues of mine who live and work in London.  Decor is fantastic, as is service and wine selection, however I felt some of the flavors to be somewhat mismatched and unusual...and by that I mean that the balance seemed off between some of the herb selections used in the dishes.  Pan-fried duck breast was good but again, the flavor seemed somewhat off and I found the duck to be a bit chewy.  The lavosh crackers with hazelnut oil was a nice try on creativity but missed the mark in terms of finding a good balance of flavors.  Spiced buttermilk cod was the highlight of the meal and deserved five stars.   I would recommend any of the fish dishes without hesitation.

14xcfWGga6QoGIuQyz8MZg.text: After a long enduring battle amongst the throngs of tourist on Regent Street and the many stores we decided to step into (as if these very stores didn't exist back in NYC!), we arrived at Nopi without any expectations. For starters we ordered 2 dishes the organic prawns and the roasted pumpkin. The organic prawns was a immediate introduction to what the rest of our dining journey would be, ABSOLUTE FLAVOR OVERLOAD to the taste buds! For the main course we ordered the smoked ricotta and the 28 day dry aged sirloin. I was a bit hesitant at first with the additional ingredients for the sirloin since I normally prefer just a dash of salt and pepper on aged sirloin. If I can steal this recipe I would without any hesitation! The meat was perfectly cooked at medium and the combination of the anchovy butter (I normally hate anchovy), king oyster mushroom, and alfalfa made the combination as perfect as the 92 Olympic Dream Team! This dish is definitely now on my list of must haves before crocking! To cap off the meal we ordered the banana brioche for dessert which basically has put Nopi forever engrained into my brain when I think of London. I will definitely be back the next time I cross the pond!

fh6e4nCSFKjDI6Wd51EnTw.text: Ottolenghi did not disappoint!! Being aware of many of his adorable dishes from the cookbooks, the moment I knew about my pending trip to London, I made a reservation weeks ahead of time as a spontaneous visit would not have had a chance to be successful. NOPI is one of several locations and very central, and by the way not excessively priced. The interior design was elegant modern, hip and yet warmly welcoming as if it was a table at the home kitchen. In fact, the lower level was exactly that with 2 very large shared table right next to the open kitchen and the backwall shelves with Ottolenghi merchandise. The noise level was significant, making conversations a bit of a challenge. But in the end, there was no time to talk, as one had to indulge into the beautifully and oh so delicious dishes. With all items to be shared, the waiter recommended 3 smaller items per person whereby a main dish would count as two. That was to the point and provided a nice tour through the menu list and still left space for a dessert. Burrata with Peaches, Roasted Beetroot, Mizo Glazed Hake, Crushed New Potatoes (P.S. glad they don't offer old ones), Twice Cooked Half Chicken were superbly done. The Strawberry Mess was not a mess at all to say the least. Great dinner!

photos.caption: Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom
Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom
Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom

jN6a0qDf96BLwUzDhGaaqw.text: I wanted so much to love this place after making many a delicious dish from the Ottolenghi cookbooks, but alas, it was no stunner, especially at the price point.  Perhaps we simply came on an off night.  But regardless, I will not be returning.  Our server was attentive and had great recommendations for food (and the items we enjoyed the least were ones she had not recommended), but when we asked about drinks, she said she didn't drink and then proceeded to tell us what the most popular drinks were.  I understand not drinking, but at an establishment such as this, at least be prepared to talk about which ones are supposed to be well balanced and so forth, based on what other servers you trust or the bartender conveys.  Worth getting -- - Truffle parmesan polenta crisps with homemade aioli:  the star of the meal, perfectly crisp, yet not oily, thick polenta fries with a nice texture of cornmeal on the outside, lusciously soft with a hint of truffle and parmesan on the inside, lovely with the aioli.  - Herdwick mutton shawarma, kohlrabi, pickled watermelon, yoghurt, flatbread:  nicely shredded, tender mutton, that paired really well with this combination of toppings, especially the bright watermelon (genius)! - Aubergine appetizer (had it been properly executed):  based on all the rave Yelp reviews, we got these thick slices of tender, roasted eggplant, smothered on top with an almond yoghurt, red peppers, and ground spiced almonds.  The first bite I has was fantastic.  But then, we discovered that the second half of our dish was crazy oversalted.  My biggest regret is not sending it back because it was clearly a mistake.  But it was virtually inedible.  - Michoacan Sherbet cocktail with Michoacan Mezcal, yuzu, fino sherry,barberry syrup, curry leaf -- really well balanced with just a touch of smoke, not too sweet, truly lovely- Banana and Cardamom cocktail with Pampero Blanco rum, Velvet Falernum, banana, cardamom honey, bitters, apple, lime -- again quite balanced and not too banana-eySkip--- Chickpea appetizer:  Meh.  It needed some crunch.  I liked the flavor combination of the tomato sauced chick peas with crumbled goat cheese, some mint and cilantro, but it needed something else to tie it together, and much more cheese, mint, and cilantro, to balance out the ginormous heap of chickpeas. - Pan fried sea bream, smoked cod's roe, beans, samphire, pickled grapes:  Good but unremarkable and unmemorable.  Just a good piece of tender white fish, a bit lacking in flavor except when you have a bite with a bit of grape.

0u-Um6U0c5rrCnH9Fbnzhg.text: This is our second time to London in the past 10 years, though our palate has changed dramatically (for the better I presume!). Our London friends took us to NOPI for lunch - overall an excellent experience! Though pricy, the ambiance is what you may expect, and the service excellent. We were blown away by some of the dishes, and others we liked though were not impressed to the same degree. We loved the roasted aubergine (eggplant) with almond yogurt and beef bavette wjth shiitake ketchup and morning glory. I would say the morning glory was over salted by itself though if you pair with the beef it was perfect. Other dishes we tried that were good (but not as extraordinary) include lavosh, couchette (zucchini) and manouri fritters, spiced potato cake, and Cumbrian pork chops.

67LawuDUc6ZkaSdJ4i1KBg.text: It might be wise to make a reservation, but we did not.  Eric R. had picked most of our meals in London and said, "This is your chance - what is the one meal you want?"  I figured we ought to go to an Ottolenghi restaurant, and off we went to NOPI.  We sat at the dining bar on the main level, and had an excellent bartender/server in Wojtek.  He had a great sense of humor, was patient, and described the food when we asked about it.  I started with an iced tea, but as that is not the norm in this part of the world, it was more like a mocktail with a splash of hot tea and something else.  He made two for one and gave one to Eric R.He suggested we share four to five dishes.  Our first dish was the roasted eggplant with almond yogurt and chilies.  It was served cold and was absolutely delicious!  We also received complimentary bread with very delicious olive oil.  Our next dish was the mutton schwarma which had a lot of delicious scallions (my favorite veggie!) plus watermelon and pita.  We also got the burrata with coriander seed and apricot, and the crispy trout marinated with koji with labneh and radish, topped with yuzu kosho.  We ended up having the strawberry mess for dessert, our first version of the eton mess we had ever had.  It was quite delicious with meringue, whipped cream, strawberries, and sorbet.  Eric R. finished with a pot of jasmine tea.  We loved the ambiance, the food, and the service.  I would highly recommend coming here!  The downstairs section has communal tables.  Also, visit the restroom here - the bathroom is like a magical mirrored trippy-ville!

photos.caption: Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Strawberry mess
Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Rainbow trout
Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Mutton schwarma

gu1B8kQy5srwM5tkGFg-EQ.text: Was beyond excited to try NOPI as I'm obsessed with the ottolenghi cookbooks. I sat at the bar as I was dining solo on a business. The bar tender was super friendly and didn't make it awk at all like sim do with a solo diner. I asked him for a few suggestions on popular dishes as well as how many to order.I chose the roasted aubergine with labneh and pistachio, rainbow trout, and a side of the potatoes. All of the dishes were awesome, really don't have any complaints at all. Was very satisfied after the 3 dishes and 2 pieces of bread and olive oil. Could have eaten more since it was so good, but didn't want to be too full. Only wish was that there were a few dips on the menu such as a hummus or babbaganoush.

EgbdbRU_aGK4YU67Co_yrA.text: I loved this restaurant when I visited two years ago.  Sadly, it seems to have gone downhill a bit based on my recent visit.  The chickpeas lacked flavor (too many chickpeas relative to the tomato sauce, goat cheese, and herbs), and portions of the aubergine were oversalted.  On the plus side, the cocktails were absolutely fantastic (I tried the banana cardamom cocktail and was pleasantly surprised) and the truffle parmesan polenta crisps (thick stalks of polenta, dipped into truffle aioli) were out of this world.

vR9W04cWyW0JT2whzWrJvQ.text: I liked it...but I didn't love it. I had been really excited to try it here but left underwhelmed. What I did love: the cocktail nuts they gave us when we waited. SO yummy. The aubergine appetizer...so unexpectedly delicious.What I didn't love: everything else, from the cilantro-y cocktail to the bland burrata, to the basic chickpeas. I would go back for the aubergine.

fv-OMmwk-JxZFUFOKwfFWw.text: Ordered the first five appetizers listed and could not decide which was best - each was delicious.  Will definitely come back to work through the menu.   Ate at the Bar and Patrick was great company.  Get a table upstairs or eat at the bar.

f6d_-wzMasDBdThKw5Xqzg.text: Surprisingly underwhelming. Lured by an available 6pm reservation and an abundance of stellar reviews, my boyfriend and I were excited to dine at Nopi. The interior is contemporary yet classic, with a primarily white and gold decor scheme, and romantic low lighting. Elegant, but still casual-no dress code. The staff were all genuinely friendly, welcoming, and knowledgeable of the menu. Our waiter recommended a unique wine that we really enjoyed-I cannot remember the name, but you will find no shortage of wine here. Their wine and craft cocktail list is outstanding.Unfortunately, the food was a different story. The complimentary bread starter was overly chewy, with a thick crust and served only with a side of olive oil. It needed balsamic vinegar or something else to flavor it, as it was quite bland on its own. The menu offers a concise selection of Mediterranean fusion dishes, separated into 4 categories-Nibbles, Starters/Dishes To Share, Mains, and Sides. I was pleased to find an abundance of vegetarian options which could easily be modified to be made vegan.We started with the Roasted Beetroot, which is served with a miso yoghurt, sesame, and garlic. The beetroot was cooked perfectly, but the marinade was much too salty. Beets are naturally salty, and the addition of several other salty toppings just did not work in this dish. My boyfriend got the popular Burrata with blood orange starter and was equally unimpressed. He barely touched his main, the Duck, saying it was inedibly salty. I got the Chickpea pancake, which was just okay. The pancake itself was not good. The only prominent flavor was curry powder, and it was slightly burnt on the bottom. I enjoyed the fresh salad and pickled chili on top, but the dressing was overwhelmingly, again, salty. The flavors were wildly non-cohesive, so much so that I separated the components onto different plates on the table. It is a shame that everything had to be over salted and over seasoned, because the base ingredients were undoubtedly high quality. £120 felt wildly overpriced for this mediocre meal. We will not be back.

QB2F4mx3v7T4Qa2E8kh6HA.text: NOPI is ridiculously good and is a must-stop for anyone traveling in London. I came here for brunch, and simply had one of the most well-prepared and comforting meals in my life.For brunch, we ordered:- Shakshuka (braised eggs, piquante tomato sauce, smoked labneh). Perfectly seasoned and cooked. I've eaten a lot of this dish before, and this had to be in my top 2.- Black rice, coconut milk, banana, mango. Not overly sweet and well balanced. Would have loved some more mango in the dish, but can't complain too much.- Hot Chocolate. Velvety goodness.- Bacon with honey. After eating so much British "bacon" for the past few days, you cannot imagine how delicious real bacon was.One of the best things about NOPI is that it has earlier opening hours than other similar places, so for those of you who have to travel in the morning, I definitely recommend dropping by this place. Just don't forget to make a reservation - you won't regret it!

photos.caption: Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Black rice, coconut milk, banana, mango
Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Bacon
Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Shakshuka (braised eggs, piquante tomato sauce, smoked labneh)

lsdLdMnKQsnJtS0-B0GOtg.text: As a caveat, I went here because I have his books so my expectations were high.  So overall the food was good but I kept anchoring it on the things I made from the book and many other people have.  It is obviously an unfair comparison because if you know how to somewhat cook, you're likelier going to suit to your tastes. The vegetables you get are likelier to be better (i.e. from a local farmer and not from a large supplier, etc).. So my rating is 4.5 starsTrying to distangle that, I think that the food is well prepared.  I only ordered vegatarian things not because I am but because I have in my head that he has made a name in this area...  In a nutshell, warm stuff is way better than the cold items.  The cold items are prepared well in advanced and is set in a buffet like table.  The warm items are pretty good.  I would recommend the cheese cake dish, the falafel and the basic chips.  Didnt like the crudite and the burrata.

4yX-3uyhP1shAGqUo0zsvw.text: We stumbled upon NOPI after wandering around Soho with no restaurant in our sites. Luckily I looked on my app and found this spot.They didn't have enough seats in the main dining hall so they brought us downstairs to the communal tables. Even though we were seated in the corner, it didn't feel that uncomfortable and we were able to enjoy our meal without a hitch.We ordered the following:pork bellygreen beansradicchioscallopsburrataI was surprised to find everything to be incredibly fresh. An LA friend told me that's I'd be disappointed with the quality of produce in the London restaurants and this restaurant definitely proved her wrong. The green beans were especially crisp and fresh as well as the radicchio.Service was attentive the whole night and we were just smiling throughout the whole meal. Highly recommended spot to come, especially if you're in Soho.

IJ8ptySYQKZws0H9iIlhMA.text: Hubby has been cooking recipes from the Nopi cook book like a mad scientist and every single one was amazing. We booked this before we left for the U.K.  I hate to say it, because we looked forward to this experience so much, but we were both underwhelmed and disappointed. Maybe we were spoiled by  our local Charleston, SC superstar. McCrady's tasting menu runs circles around this place. Our high expectations were daunted. Yes there were some good items, but when two very talented chefs collaborate, your expectations are to be blown away. I just couldn't recommend it.

kEw6N_G_pUCffZk5D_evtA.text: I Ran into London during a layover from Heathrow and stopped by this place. It's one of the least touristy places in a pretty touristy area -- not the cheapest, but definitely a great find. The food was a great combination of Mediterranean and Asian flavors. Staff was also super friendly and helpful. I definitely recommend this place if you're looking for a lunch or dinner to try out their great flavor combinations.

photos.caption: Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom

gBZQarmeEjyXMPgW1LP-CA.text: A wonderful meal! It is so nice to eat somewhere where the vegetarian options get as much attention as the other stuff.The aubergine is like a dream - we ordered a second one because we could not get enough. The chickpea pancake is very, very large. Delicious but probably better for sharing than to eat in one sitting.For me, I think it is worth the expense just to eat that aubergine again.

fm-atLvyYRY77n2Bc3F8aw.text: I was so excited to eat here because I own three of Ottigeni's cookbooks.  I was so disappointed.  Nothing special here and definitely no recipes from any of his books. This is a "sharing" restaurant.  The prices per sharing plate run 10-25 pounds (15-30 dollars) and there is only enough on each plate for two people to take a couple bites.  Not sure what all the hype is about.  If you want to spend $120 (three plates, a cocktail and a desert) and leave hungry by all means go here.Wine list is also subpar - they offer a wine from Palestine" in their list of six wines so not sure why they feel the need to be political when wines from West Bank not really that good

1K9iS-z35Zdn4h_4VwwCvw.text: I really enjoyed this restaurant. We are healthy eaters and when I read farm to table I assumed every dish was helping. That was not the case with the pork dish which Robert did not enjoy because all the fat it contained. But the other dishes were healthy, flavorful and interesting.

photos.caption: Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Farm to table kind of restaurant

JuePnOJxm_m80Ijpr_KTfA.text: solid five stars! many small plates which is great for sampling. I was with a vegetarian and never felt like there wasn't enough meat protein. everything was fantastic. standouts were: burrata with peaches, octopus, courgette fritters and the chickpea pancake.service was really nice, friendly, helpful and very knowledgeable about the menu. good value too, even though it's a pricey restaurant. I can't wait to return

KS4QqbE3Tktn1Xb-615KYQ.text: I came to NOPI without knowing what to expect because I had never heard of Ottelenghi in the United States. My experience in London fine dining has been nothing short of spectacular. We ordered from the nibbles menu "Mixed seed lavosh, burnt spring onion dip," from the vegetables menu "Burrata, loquats, verjus, coriander seeds," and "Chargrilled Everleigh farm asparagus, miso tahini, poppy seeds." As a main, we shared "Chickpea pancake, spiced peas, tomato, picked chili, yuzu." All of the food was finely prepared and beautifully presented. I prefer sweet wines over dry, and could not find one that suited my palate. The waitress, Tes, asked if "everything was good," and I expressed my wish for a sweeter wine. I have yet to find a Riesling in London. Tes was extremely patient with me (and I tried really hard not to test it, as I felt like I was too fussy already). She brought two sample glasses of what she thought were sweeter white wines. While those didn't satisfy me either, I expressed my gratitude to her (and here) and via the Ottelenghi info/contact e-mail address. Clearly, the staff are trained to cater to any customer's discriminating palate. I would return to NOPI or his eponymous restaurants any day I am in London. Don't miss out on this exquisite dining experience!

Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Chickpea pancake, spiced peas, tomato, pickled chilli, yuzu.
