gighNtb5wZ3Z-J37y7h39A.text: WOW. Just wow. One of the best meals that I've had in a long time. Made a reservation for downstairs. Downstairs includes public group seating and you'll be seated next to strangers. You also have a view of the kitchen. Met some folks traveling from Germany and we had a great conversation.NOPI's menu changes on a regular basis. I ordered the charred hispi cabbage, the Korean inspired sirloin, and the pineapple with coconut ice cream for dessert. The waiter recommended the banana and cardamom cocktail. I wouldn't have changed a thing.Eat here as soon as you can! You won't regret it!

photos.caption: Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom

YAttmEWT4SGFR7IbfK6s3w.text: Excellent atmosphere and decadent food. As a party of eight we ordered two of everything on the platters menu. Check out the bathrooms - it's like Alice in Wonderland!!!

x4jLvThTYS64BzaU2XzKag.text: After owning three of his Cook Books I was really looking forward to this meal but based on the cost and food quality it ended up being just barely acceptable. Burrata Cheese: This was kind of gimmicky. Cheese came out presented beautifully but lacked the texture and quality that Burrata cheese is known for. I'm unsure where they source the cheese but this was certainly one of the worst versions of this meal I have ever had.Eggplant: This is one of their signature dishes but when we ordered it it looked like something that had be premade earlier in the day and was sitting in a fridge waiting to be ordered. It certainly was visually pleasing but lacked any complex flavours and was only a "single layer" of taste.Trout: Was overly salted and incredibly fishy. I don't believe they had sourced the freshest fist for this place on this occasion. The service also lacked something. Food arrived prior to the wine and we had to hunt down a waiter to finally get some delivered. Had this been a $100 meal for two people it would have been acceptable however at $300 for two people I was thoroughly unimpressed and would not return. It wasn't horrible, but it wasn'the amazing culinary experience I was expecting.

zlF7KrYuZx0hChueu2Qp_w.text: I love the cookbooks and the restaurant met my very high expectations! Wonderful food and lovely staff, all committed to their work and eager to tell you about it. You can check out the larder in the lower level room. We liked eating upstairs. Can't wait to go back, even though it requires crossing the pond to do so!

1Hatj2ACi0_frbGV4M-65g.text: I will begin with my only let down: that be of appellation. NoPi (North of Piccadilly?). Really? Let's leave the abbreviated micro-neighbourhood naming to New York...BUT! Otto-legend-i does it again and again!The most esculent food.The most sophisticated decor.The most sought-after location.The most gracious staff.My dining experience here was nothing short of perfect. The menu is designed to be tapas-style, whereby sharing dishes are sorted under meat, fish, vegetarian and dessert headings, with about 3-4 small plates recommended per person (so if you come with enough people, the more you get to sample!).As every morsel of food emerged from the open kitchen, gratefully onto our communal timber table in the casual pantry-dining area downstairs, disbelief spread as no-one could fathom the possibility of the next dish tasting superior to the previous. But it happened. Again, and again.I could never shun anything consumed here, but to torture myself, and select the favourites... the most memorable of the elongated-shortlist would be Valdeón cheesecake, the pork belly with pear, the banana-leaf wrapped gurnard but the roasted aubergine absolutely stole the whole show.The contemporary retrofit works very successfully. The nautically-themed brass detailing provides beautifully cast coat hooks, light fixtures and ironmongery alike. A trip to the bathroom is a must just the experience a most fascinating hall of mirrors- congratulations if you can find your way back to the restaurant through the correct door on first attempt!

cn5pV7gW2HUEHTvHEqXaUQ.text: An exceptional place with exceptional food. We were looking for a place to have dinner on New Year Eve in our first visit with my daughters to London. We wanted something special and we got it. They were serving a special menu for the night, but I am sure it is representative of the quality you would get there any night. They were very accommodating in allowing my two daughters to order a la carte and thus not pay full price for their dinners. The service was impeccable and the sommelier was wonderful with suggesting wines by the glass that we loved. Here are just some entree title to give you an idea:Burrata, clementine, coriander seedsValdeon cheescake, pickled beetroot, hazelnut, thyme honey (amazing)Sea bream, fresh coconut, pickled ginger, mint, peanutsTwice-cooked baby chicken, lemon myrtle salt, chili sauceRoast sirloin, spinach and asparagus, truffle vinegrette, Belper Knolle (exceptional)Don't know what else to say. Worth a trip from another country and met my New Year's expectations.

F4f638eswKqwXbmLzS5ciA.text: Expensive but delicious. The scallops and the sweet potatoes were the group favorite 2 dishes. Service was pretty good. Phenomenal start when we showed up, getting us nuts and olives to snack on and a drink menu right away. Service got a bit slow at our table but not a big deal. Had some great deserts to finish the meal. Cakes with toffee cream were probably the best of the three deserts. Hi plate mousse with pop rocks was unique and delish.

U6u2WWMiaoyBqmet76Q3Nw.text: I go to this restaurant every time I visit London, which is basically every month (just so that you understand my dedication). Reservations can be a bit tough at times but this place is definitely worth it. I'm a vegetarian so I can't comment on the meat dishes. We usually end up ordering just about every vegetarian starter and it works out perfectly. I also prefer getting a bunch of starters to share vs. getting a main. They switch their menu every 3-4 months but the burrata starter is my favorite and has always been on the menu. The drinks are great as well. Try the grapefruit and lychee cooler and the kumquat and passionfruit. Bathroom is pretty interesting - make sure to check it out...which is pretty easy after having some of their yummy drinks.

th5jP5PtDRgWk6k9YppzWA.text: Pretty darn great. We had a number of small plates which were all good, the one with sauerkraut on the side was particularly memorable. My roast was solid and others liked their duck. The real EPIPHANY of the evening was the herbal side salad with fresh dill and WFI...mint omigosh the combination was amazing and it would seem to be recreatable home. The atmosphere and staff were cool and the wine was great, but again even though the orderer didn't need any help the waiter had zero insight into what would shine with what. I realize this isn't a 4GBP place but how hard is it to throw Wine for Dummies at your employees or give them a color coded diagram to memorize. One would think some knowledge would be unavoidable given your working milieu, but I guess I'm off base.Anyhow, go there!

l4PY1XYDBUdzBzTGpzFiVQ.text: I came here on my birthday and had a delicious dinner. This is true, down to earth, honest to goodness deliciousness. Service was excellent, with still and sparkling tap water offered for free and replenished frequently. To our questions about ingredients, our server either knew the answers or found out quickly. Our six dishes came quite quickly, but not all at once, and we never felt rushed. Moreover, our server made an extra effort to try to find out a retailer where we might be able to buy the wine that we chose (the "Biancadicaselle"). Our server displayed the right balance of being attentive without being obsequious throughout the meal.The food itself was very, very good. The vegetables used were seasonal (swedes, carrots, grated brussel sprouts, beetroot, greens) and were supplemented by spices, yogurts/cheese, and savoury sauces. In general, the food was perhaps a little salty, but as full-time vegetarians with a seasonal-veg commitment, we are accustomed to blandness by the end of a long winter so perhaps others would not think anything was amiss.Portion sizes were fine--we ordered six dishes between the two of us (guys) and we actually felt full before the end of the evening.

8BlwfmYaim3pCsCx7mS6Mw.text: We came here without a reservation yesterday (having been defeated by the queue at Pitt Cue) and were pleased to be able to secure a table at the bar for lunch. Although we have eaten at Ottolenghi before we were not really sure what to expect but were largely pleased with what was on offer - a series of tapas dishes which show ingredients and culinary influences from around the world.Some dishes were a little over powering, perhaps suffering from one ingredient or influence too many.  However, others were an absolute delight.  I particularly enjoyed the roasted aubergine which was served with black garlic, harissa and pine nuts.  The aubergine was absolutely stunning and its accompaniments complimented rather than detracted from its smokey flavour.  Another great dish was the gurnard cooked in a banana leaf and served with a pineapple sambal.  The fish was perfectly cooked and its delicate spicing was a perfect foil for the sambal.Somewhat at odds with the modernity of the food however, is the ambiance of NOPI which is a little too clinical.  Perhaps this is a reaction to the organised chaos which makes Ottolenghi such fun. However, something, for me at least, wasn't quite right.  This said, the staff are nothing but pleasant and were extremely helpful explaining some of the more esoteric ingredients on the menu.Special mention should go to the wine list which is quite exceptional.  I would be very happy to spend a fortune working through all of the interesting bottles on offer and this would be a great place to take someone who was really interested in wine.

ffTXzk5UNKARR7X3jJMiVA.text: OH MY GOD every morsel was better than the next. Tons of vegetarian options, and the chicken was good as well - juicy and dark and savory in a sweet soy-based marinade. The waiter recommended six items between two, and we had eight. A little too much, but it's only too much of a good thing. Each was 5-8 pounds. The best were the cauliflower with ricotta and raisins and the sweet potatoes with goat's cheese and figs... oh, and the lavash with aubergine-fig-goat curd dip. mmmmm.We ordered a fresh tomato salad and didn't like it as much - not that it wasn't great, but that in the presence of so many delicious foods it was only ok. They didn't charge us and said it was a new item and would be reconsidered for the next menu.We also ordered the non-alco cocktails - basically really fancy juices - and although pricey, they were mmm mmm good. If I came again, I'd like to sit at the communal table downstairs!

kszl2DBZjteszF2Fu3Zziw.text: Great place for a nice dinner with friends! I've been here two times and both the food and the service has been just great both times. Can truly recommend the chicken, extremely good! Also great wine and trendy decore! I will definitely come back!

lm4Tu7nnvt-0dJxG4G8QoQ.text: Nopi food is out of bounce ... Sooooo delicious, i had the baby chicken and the sea bass. Not to mention they serve different type of striking salad ... Welldpne chief and Management of nopi

cSvConmjGBkaIKB03u1hMQ.text: Probably the worst service i received in london - as we didn't get two items that we ordered (both of which were our more interesting picks). As the waiter did not tell us in a timely manner, we did not have a good balance of hot and cold dishes, saucy and dry, meaty and full of vegetable, which might have negatively impact our dining experience. As such, we didn't think that the dishes were interesting enough or well balanced enough. What we got (about 7 different dishes shared by 3) were good, but didn't warrant a repeat visit. There were also no standouts.A few tips for those who are going to try this place:- make sure you're seated upstairs and are not rushed. They may have agreed to accomodate you, but tell you that you have to leave at a certain time - go another time, you need time to enjoy the meal as service is slow.- they will tell you that you need a main plus two starters, i personally think an average eater would be happy with a starter and a main- those familiar with asian food or indonesian cuisine (the chilli!) --- The twice cooked chicken and chili sauce is a common asian dish. It's almost like a mix of ayam kalasan or chinese five spiced chicken (though not sure if its 5 spice, it might be just sweet soy sauce). It's delicious but also 3x its usual price. Worth a try for those who have no idea what i'm talking about. Not sure what part of this dish is mediterranean.

rGe8EJ5cuGG5OxAcLNxR4Q.text: It's not cheap to eat here, but it is fantastic.The ambience manages to be opulent without being too over-the-top: whilst there were plenty of Chelsea-ites here, it didn't feel tacky at all: just the right level of statement.As mentioned the toilets are an experience in themselves.The menu evidently changes pretty rapidly, since none of the dishes I'd read about in reviews were on the menu. As told by the menu, we ordered 6 dishes in total for the two of us, which turned out to be just the right amount. The food is delivered "as it's done" according to the friendly and knowledgable waitress. At one point I was concerned we'd run out of table space, but thankfully they'd obviously timed everything carefully.We ordered a £40 quid bottle of red, which I thought was rather disappointing for the price point.The dishes were delivered in menu order, which as we'd ordered two veg, two fish, and two meat, ended up in a rather suitable pattern.Burrata with peach and fennel seeds: delicious, the mozarella-ball-like cheese perfectly unguent and creamy, and the anise setting it off nicelyValdeon cheesecake (yes, we had two cheeses): probably the highlight, a great depth of flavour and a perfect consistency, with the beetroots a great companionSoftshell crab: Never ordered this before, but I liked it an awful lot. Came coated in breadcrumbs and was crabby without being overly soOtak-otak: this was some perfectly-cooked seafood (squid amongst others) in a lovely coconut sauce, all wrapped up inside a banana leaf (or something like it)Rabbit pastilla: AKA rabbit pie. I've always suspected I don't really like rabbit, and whilst this was obviously well-executed, it turns out I'm right.Beef sirloin: this was delivered almost carpaccio-style with cheese flaked on top. I wasn't totally sold on this one, I must admit.We couldn't resist dessert. We chose the doughnuts with berries (delicious) and the kaffir lime meringue (equally so, we argued for quite some time about which was better). Even better, on asking the waitress for a drink recommendation to match, she steered towards a glass of dessert wine (the cheapest one) for one, and an excellent sake for the other. I'm not much of a sake buff, but this was really very nice.

4Aa8Bd93-ST2il2-mc2hWg.text: I don't understand the hype for this place. I'd heard about Ottolenghi through an IG account I follow, then saw the great reviews on Yelp for NOPI. So while I was in London on vacation, I picked this place as a splurge meal. There were three of us, and we were at a communal table downstairs since I'd waited so long to make a reservation. But the atmosphere was still cool, since you're looking right at the kitchen (you can't see much, though, and our food still came from upstairs?). We split a few different dishes, which is what the restaurant recommends. We ordered the truffled polenta chips, baby chicken, grilled quail, seared scallops, and courgette fritters. They also brought us the Ottolenghi spiced nuts while we waited for our table, which were one of our favorite parts of the meal. The quail was also really good, and the chicken and scallops were fine, but nothing else was that great. It may be that I'm just not used to this type of food, but if I were going to splurge on a meal I'd go somewhere else.The bathroom is really cool, though - a highlight of our dinner. :)

o0k95S8h8U3tn41NWpQlmw.text: I thought we arrived hours earlier than my original reservation, but we actually were a day earlier (my mistake). The manager was very nice and after a short wait, we got a table.  The cocktails were excellent. My companion enjoyed the old fashioneds  (but I don't like vanilla or rooibos flavors). I loved the Banana and Cardamom cocktail. Frankly, I think I would have been happy to just drink a few of those and eat the spiced nuts.  Note: The nuts weren't hot-spicy, just full-flavored. If you have any interest in saving room for dessert - 3 small plates would be enough for two. We had five and were too stuffed to consider dessert. The fish, the lamb, and the aubergine were the best food choices we tried. They weren't large portions, but delicious and filling. I liked the toasted coriander seeds, but found the nectarine sauce with the burrata too cloying; however, my companion thought it was great. Every item we tried demonstrated a deep knowledge of spices and seasoning. While everything was flavorful and delicious, nothing was overpowering. I've seen Ottolenghi cookbooks everywhere and was excited to try one of his restaurants.. After this experience, I doubt I'll be cooking any of these items at home, but I think I'd like to try some of the other restaurants in the group.

_oWc27otohgDF-jP2bdG_w.text: The hottest October 1st on record, coincided with a birthday meal with Mrs E. First up was to order a cocktail whilst coordinating what Mrs E and I would choose from the 30+ tapas style dishes. I went for Pineapple and Sage Martini and Mrs E had lychee and grapefruit.Bread was served with a great dhaal after which we piled into a tomato salad with a light wasabi sauce. The highlights were the Carpaccio, the rabbit Pastilla and the soft-shell crab. The only disappointment was a beetroot and hazelnut Cheesecake which despite the description came across like a gratin dauphinoise and the prawns in curry sauce which were ok but not brilliant.The desserts were excellent, Mrs E had a Peanut ice-cream and I had Pecan Financiers.All in all a great night and would definitely recommend.

YR-FGRzgMnQyBHGV2DrvyQ.text: 3 savory plates per person?  NEED 5.  I came home and ate a sandwich.  It was a goddamn good sandwich though.  I digress.But this place has 5-star potential.  Thank you Yotam for a more restauranty less canteeny place with flavor packed, mini sharing plate goodness.  Highlights of the evening were the Burrata (capitalization necessary, MOAR!!!), veal carpaccio, poached sea bass, and the beef brisket croquettes.  And the bathroom, if you're a vain little ass like myself.  The delicious sounding cocktails were a little bit off, proportion-wise, and I had to send my drink back for another shot.  Resisted the urge to jump behind the bar to show em how it's done and then potentially go into a sluttier than Coyote Ugly status to class the place up.Hey lady waitress with the wobbly arm, do some weights or else you're going to get fired soon for dropping everything you touch.  Good acoustics for a restaurant though, definitely.Since it's a little bit on the pricier side and is the new place to be seen, apparently, be prepared for England's version of My Super Sweet 16...in which prepubescents that have raided the MAC store prior to dinner (then decided to wear all purchases on face) plop down next to you with their blackberries and gossip about who's friend is marrying which Eton kid.  I almost slapped a bitch.  In a good way though!!!

0AozOV1PZHJNMipgSV-avg.text: A little too clean cut perhaps but some good modern takes on Israeli food. Not disappointing but perhaps it did not reach expectations given The reputation. Safe inoffensive flavours, good for London, but average compared to what you might find in the Middle East.

FtHAlF6xrRi3jQUwoWziBg.text: This was definitely one of our favorite meals during our trip to England in September.  Our server was friendly and helpful.  He clearly knew the menu very well and explained a few items that were unfamiliar to us.  I loved that we could order small plates and try several things on the menu.  Everything was fresh, flavorful, and delicious!As an American, everything seems expensive in London, but this meal was SO delicious.....we still felt like it was a great deal!  If you're in London, you must try Nopi!One additional note: They abide by the "two hour" reservation rule for a table.  It didn't seem to be a problem that we ran a little over!

x0BmUkrRm9TubCGtdvHHnA.text: Beautiful restaurant. Excellent service. Unfortunately the food - while beautiful - isn't very good. The chief is trying way too hard. Too many flavors going on in every dish we tried (about 8 of them). What ends up happening is that the overall flavor is ambiguous and muddied. This is the first restaurant we tried here in London. Hopefully the rest are better.

eTBibCKunu6Wa22AYusI-A.text: It was a rainy day and i wanted a little treat so popped in and sat the bar for lunch.  I had only three starters so can't comment on the mains.  On recommendation from the waiter, I tried the courgette and manouri fritters, roasted aubergine and seared scallops. Of the three, the scallops were by far the best - well seasoned, fresh and served with shiitake and enoki mushrooms and some sort of seaweed. It was delicious. I wanted to order another one!  The eggplant was perfectly tender and served with what seemed like light cheese topped with roasted nuts and pomegranate seeds. Very refreshing and clean tasting. Finally, I tried the courgette fritters which are mixed with what looked like shallots and manouri, which reminded me of light ricotta. I liked this the least. They were not greasy (good thing) but also flavoured with cardamon which overwhelmed the taste of the dish.  They were ok but given the waiter called it out as a signature dish, it could have worked a lot harder to gain that praise. Overall, some very nice, simple food.  I was expecting a bit more wow factor given how expensive it was (£40 for three starters and a glass of wine) but it was good afternoon treat, albeit lousy value for money.  The scallops made the difference as well as the service.

A6AKGlN-ow3rp8Rocka8Ug.text: Loved everything about this meal. We booked downstairs so were able to watch the kitchen in action. The service was professional but not too much. Every dish we tried was delicious. I love Ottolenghi and I loved NOPI.

rEeYPIV7aIy0yZW2siAi5g.text: Nopi has to be counted among the best restaurants in London.  It certainly bests my favourite spots in San Francisco.  The food is a revelation: it is imaginative, and comes without any of the the performance art and navel gazing that drags down so many other modern restaurants.  The focus is on small plates (many of which are served at room temperature), unique flavor pairings, and tons of vegetables.Don't miss the burrata with white peach and coriander seeds, the fried courgette flower filled with riccotta, or the pressed duck confit with sour plum jam and walnut horseradish cream.The downstairs dining room is more informal than the upstairs, but the upstairs isn't particularly snooty to begin with.  Pricing is entirely appropriate for the quality of the food.  Service is fine, but not really the point of the show.

tj9I4ac6e1G32iyE3kTqpg.text: Food was pretty good, if a bit expensive for what it is.I had the gourgette and octopus. The dessert, crazy strawberries, was fantastic, and so was the coffee.

HQ9TxX-dmaTYJ_Q5kbQgTw.text: Ok, let me add my mustard! (This is the literal translation of a German saying, meaning that you would like to add your opinion to the topic at hand.)I LOVED NOPI. I had been very much looking forward to trying out, as I had heard so many good things about it. And fortunately, despite having high hopes for this place, my expectations were not only met, but even succeeded!The thing I loved about this place is definitely not the price tag...it's the fact that the chefs can do so many wonderful things to vegetables. Think about it this way: usually, you get vegetables as a side dish and they come dressed up in clothes from Old Navy or Monsoon. Here at NOPI, the vegetables are the stars and they undergo a transformation by folks like Vivian Westwood or Alexander McQueen.The best way to sample as many dishes as possible, is to come with about three or four people and every person chooses between 2 and 3 dishes....you must make a reservation, especially on a busy weekend night or else you either might not be seated at all, or you might be waiting for a looooong time.And last but not least - do thy out their bathroom...it's quite a different experience as well ;-)

l8zrUkKmBksuUOeVC0gOSQ.text: Hands down the best meal of my London trip! Very trendy and upscale place that I am glad to have found in my short visit. I had the lamb chops for my entree which appeared more rare than to my liking but was actually pretty perfect. Our group of three ended up with an appetizer, entrees, drinks and dessert which came out to £160 but everyone was super satisfied with their meal. I would definitely go back if I was a local.

photos.caption: Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Lamb chops

mrudbqu63WwXB8veN0QjJQ.text: I love Ottolenghi. I love the deli, I love the sit-down restaurant in Islington, I love the cookbooks. All of it. So I was very excited to finally be eating at NOPI, which is often billed as Ottolenghi's upscale counterpart. The food was, not surprisingly, very good. Everything was fresh with interesting flavor combinations that worked very well, as is this chef group's signature. The bathrooms are something out of a nightmare. I don't even understand the purpose of designing it that way. It's a horrible hall of mirrors that I would have gotten stuck in after a couple more drinks. The music was also awful, as they were playing some sort of trying-to-be-hip up-tempo beats that just...no. Not when I'm trying to enjoy dinner. Especially not a nice dinner of small plates. The wine was delicious. Our server kind of ignored our table for stretches of time, which was surprising because she was very attentive to others. I think it was just a busy time or we seemed lower maintenance or something. We ate in the ground floor dining room, but could see the long tables in the basement overlooking the kitchen being much cozier and a nicer experience. What it comes down to is this: skip NOPI and just go to Ottolenghi. You'll have to book further in advance to get a table, but the food is on par if not better, more reasonably priced, and the atmosphere is much more fitting the type of meal you'll have. The only thing saving this place from a three star review is the quality of the food.

jFuMjaUMVGbWPwKfd0sOPA.text: What can I say about Nopi? If you're a fan of Ottolenghi then you're sure to like Nopi. The look is different. Where Ottolenghi is all minimalist white Nopi is more modern blonde wood. I like the coat hooks here. They like hangers that go directly on the wall. The hanging coats look like people facing the wall. It's funny and creepy at the same time. Similar to Nopi I recommend a reservation. I'm not sure you can get a walkin seat. I'm not sure if they even have any. I came in at lunch and they were booked until 2 PM. I was able to snag a reservation for 3 that night though. Unfortunately the rest of my party bailed but I forged on by myself. They were nice about changing the reservation and suggested I sit at the bar - more sociable to sit and chat with the bartenders than to sit by myself at a communal table. Although they do large plates I wanted to try as many different dishes as possible so went with the recommended 3 dishes which may have been a good recommendation for a bigger or hungrier person but was too much food for me. Perhaps I shouldn't have listened to those other reviewers who complained about portions because I made sure to eat all my complimentary bread. I ended up taking half of two dishes home so I could have dessert (you didn't seriously think I would pass up dessert here did you?).I took the bartenders recommendations which included: * valdeon cake - the fluffiest creamiest savory cheesecake ever, 5 stars * mackerel and green grape salsa with tobiko - nice for mackerel people, this dish doesn't disguise the mackerel, 4 stars * twice baked chicken - I didn't quite understand why this chicken was so special, 3 stars * tofu-fa with papaya young coconut and ginger syrup - a dessert that was light, refreshing and not too sweet, very unusual flavors with the tofu-fa, 5 starsDrinks were very very good. I had the saffron chase and anise/apple. I especially liked the anise/apple.Total was £70 for 3 dishes, dessert and 2 drinks - including 20% tip. For just a little more ££ my meal could have been split between 2 people.The biggest difference with Nopi are the customers. Lots of groups at Nopi celebrating who-knows-what. While I was eating at the bar a group was mingling next to me - older man with hitler mustache dressed for the opera, older guy who looked like a retired rock star, a tweedy professor and an amazoness in bright red. Soho! Gotta love it!

u0v-G6evQQTIiTWfOj2zUw.text: NOPI offered everything I want in a restaurant - good service, great food, trendy decor. I celebrated my mother's birthday here and had a lovely evening. We ordered a mixture of salads and hot starters. Each item was perfection from presentation to taste and even though we arrived quite late (post-theatre) the staff were gracious is not making us feel like we were holding them back from leaving, even as the restaurant emptied around us.Favourites: charred broccoli and marinated olives.

1PkcM4crVfA2HvRg7YTEkw.text: I've eaten here several times and really loved it. Big fan of Ottolenghi and in fact, NOPI had become probably my favorite restaurant in London. But after this last time I just don't think it's worth it any longer. I'm not sure if they've entered a "summer surge" period or what, but the prices seemed to jump about 20 percent from a few months ago, while the portion sizes dropped 20 percent, and fairly aloof service to boot. I understand this isn't a takeaway or counter-order joint, but over £200 for three people and everyone to still be hungry later is a bit ridiculous.

3QYSvUYMRHEqAbinXk-U6A.text: unlike normal, we found the restaurant first and looked at yelp second we made the reservation weeks in advance (knowing the chef's considerable reputation, and having used his recipes and cookbooks) We weren't disappointed, except by our own excitement - let me explain. We ordered almost All the signature dishes - twice cooked baby chicken, scallops (pork belly, apple, yuzu sauce), fish, and many vegetable sides, including the aubergine (eggplant) signature and burrata with nectarines , coriander and white balsamic. it was a gastronomic field day!! each dish stood on it's own, and was delicious. We became victims of our gluttony, however, when the 5 sides and 4 mains had somewhat of a collision, and at least for a couple at the table, caused a taste traffic jam...(I, however, enjoyed every minute). it's a meal we won't forget soon, but may pare back the gluttonous ordering next time. Most of the 6 of us enjoyed thoroughly and would consider it a signature meal to be re-experienced as soon as possible !!! (hope we get back to family and this restaurant in London soon!!)

6-B_Um6khq3kufb401sq4Q.text: Amazing from start to finish!  The flavors were so complex and interesting and surprising.  I could have eaten there for every meal.  A beautiful presentation!  Perfection!

HVWq9TgXJ-PnkUQgvfZ0dg.text: Below average food and akward wines. We tried a selection of eight different courses for sharing. Most of the food was quite boring. Good service.

0tZQg_NTerXfzxeZsVJOfw.text: Came back here for brunch with friends and was glad to see some quirky random things on a menu which was more affordable than lunch/dinner. I tried the black rice porridge which was a serious portion and served with the maple syrup on the side which I appreciate as I can control how sweet to go.  It wasn't as 'exciting' as I could have hoped, but certainly a solid option and presented beautifully.The friends who ordered mushrooms on toast were ecstatic though, so I might try that next time.  The hot chocolate I ordered was dark and rich, and again not too sweet (perfect) but for some reason my friend's latte never arrived. Still, worth a visit :)

NDoak_egzppzyCbNur0pxQ.text: I usually don't come out of restaurants, especially expensive ones, feeling satisfied with my experience. Nopi was a nearly perfect restaurant. I wouldn't say it was the best tasting food I have ever had, but it was the most interesting and thoughtful food experience.

oYpmJncU8r7gRe2gk7uyaQ.text: Ottolenghi is good, but Nopi is better, in my opinion. I managed to make a booking for the downstairs communal table and I really like the elegant table setting. Nopi serves small dishes, which I love, because I can sample so many different flavors at one meal. The menu here seems to be changing very frequently if not daily. The burrata, blood orange, coriander seeds and lavender oil offered very unexpected flavor, but I thought the taste of burrata was masked by the lavender a bit. i prefer the unadulterated taste of burrata more. Then came my favorite dish - roasted sweet potato with burnt aubergine yoghurt and roasted seeds. The genius of the dish was the strong smoky flavor of the aubergine yoghurt: it makes a vegetarian dish taste so satisfying. Another of the highlight was, to my surprise, twice-cooked baby chicken. I am not a big fan of chicken, but I want to lick the meat of the bone of this chicken. It was cooked Asian style with sweet soy sauce and the meat was just super flavorful and juicy. We also had octopus, pork belly and venison, and they were all pretty good as well. I love the clever usage of yogurt and nuts in different dishes. The potions here were small, but after 7 dishes my friend and i were too full to get desserts.   I will definitely come back again to try new items on the menu.

FYIdYxLO3UJqEf2j8e6JiQ.text: We had a wonderful night and this is a place with a real vibe. From the moment we arrived we had a feeling that everyone wants you to have a good night....and we did...our booking was for two hours and this was ample given the way this restaurant runs the night.The food was excellent and two dishes that stood out for us were Chicken and the Octopus...however the Aubergine and the Asparagus were really good too.....We enjoyed a wonderful bottle of Bourgone Rouge to top off a wonderful occasion. This restaurant offers excellent value for money and a destination that one could easily turn into being 'my regular' place!

QnrsQZyMf5i3p8h0rX6KEw.text: The food spoke volumes! My mother was in town from America and has two of their cookbooks at home- Jerusalum and Ottolenghi. After doing research and finding no tables available for Ottolenghi we decided to try Nopi since it had so many raving reviews. I was able to get us in downstairs for a 9.30pm meal. We arrived at 9.20pm. Table was not ready so we had to stand at the bar. They brought us an amazing homemade nuts and fabulous olives. At 9.55pm I went to the front desk to see how much longer our table would be.. which was annoying as we had been standing for 35 minutes and it was 25 minutes past our reservation time. I was a bit put off by the service as we where waiting around for forever. We finally where seated at 10pm downstairs on a crowded table, it took me another 20 minutes to flag a waiter down to ask if he could take our order. We where never greeted by our waiter when we sat down and I flagged him down the first time and he said he would be with us a moment. 20 minutes passed and I had to flag him down again to say please take our order! ( note: its 10.30 and we have been waiting an hour by now). We where never checked up on throughout our meal, never asked if we wanted another drink. For a top restaurant I wouldn't expect to have to beg a waiter to take our orders or fight for attention such as extra olive oil (we had to ask twice). The food was amazing, the service shocking. The chicken was crispy and flavorful... I cannot complain about any dishes as they where all top notch 5 star quality. The head of house eventually came down towards the end of the meal and took 2 drinks of our bill for making us wait for over 30 minutes for our table(if she didn't I would have been more upset as I felt we deserved some type of apology), which was a nice gesture. I am just still a bit shocked at the lack of attention we received downstairs from the waiters. Waiters are supposed to follow up and make sure you have everything you need, we shouldn't have to fight to flag someone down for 10-15 minutes especially if you are paying high prices for the meal. They are obviously understaffed. I would say 5 star for food, 2 star for service.. this is why I am giving a three star rating. Hopefully they solve their staffing issues and get more staff and ones that are trained to pay more attention to their clients.

photos.caption: Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Kumquat & passionfruit and rose water
Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Roasted Aubergine sorrel yoghurt radish pecans

7BirXKxNzHo_5cTpNzIExQ.text: Nopi is exactly what you would expect from a branch of the Yotam Ottelenghi empire. Incredibly high quality food and unusual flavour combinations in a nice setting, with the downside being high prices and quite small portions.We came for lunch and shared 7 of the small plates between 2. This was enough for lunch, but I would have needed a bit more to be satisfied at dinner. Stand out dishes were the scallops, chickpea & butternut squash and the grey mullet. Only disappointment was the twice cooked chicken which was the poorest value dish.The bill came to £80 with service and no drinks. About 20% higher than it should be, but an enjoyable experience nonetheless.

hJEjRIelwDpIBZ7801KFig.text: great place with a nice ambience and attentive staff. I was a little disappointed in how heavy the food was - a lot of oils and butters are used in their cooking. that being said the food was flavorful and the croquettes as good as the other reviews have said.

4vchxmGWepnihdDZVqS7Rw.text: I had such high expectations after having bought Ottolenghi's first two cookbooks and tried to make things out of them. Our meal was pretty good but not amazing. Slight imbalance of flavors here and there... I was disappointed.  I guess he is busy opening another restaurant or writing another book.

OSe0zf6got2tUE3CHVj_JQ.text: I was expecting to be blown away. And I wasn't. It was good, maybe even very good. But after all I've heard about Ottolenghi, I wanted my experience to be phenomenal. We went for brunch. Among 3 of us, we shared french toast, shakshuka, and the yogurt with fruit and granola. The shakshuka stole the show - well seasoned, well thought out. The yogurt and granola was good - each bite was addictive. Unfortunately, I found the french toast a bit dry and not very creative. I expected better!

lfXzFCTCK3zvzmlTkHtObg.text: I liked the dish I had: sole with brown butter and a side of broccoli. That said, I had such difficulty understanding this menu. I'm not a hillbilly, at least I don't think I am. There are so many ingredients on this menu that I just could not identify, far too many to provide comfort. Do you know what "kefalotyri" is? How about "borage"? "Sea speghetti"? Nope, me neither. I'd like a nice plate of "Pork neck, pig's ears, and yuzu puree" please. I'm not kidding. I worked in fine dining establishments through college and graduate school, so I'm moderately informed, but this is absurd. Does the average person know these things and I'm just out of it? Service was fine, my food was nice, the setting was casual with energy, but the menu was beyond me altogether.

dm3tRWMcC8aTzuJPO1fTAQ.text: NOPI is another delightful and thriving restaurant from Yotum Ottolenghi. NOPI is similiar to his restaurant Ottolenghi in that the flavors are bold and vibrant yet comforting and delicious. The food is sourced locally, as much as possible, and it is fresh and free of preservatives and artificial coloring. Inventive seasonal dishes are offered with both Mediterranean and Asian influences. This restaurant has community tables, similar to Ottolenghi on the lower level, but there are smaller and more formal tables on the main floor. Reservations are recommended for pre-theatre and dinner. Breakfast and lunch are also served at this location. The restaurant has a bar and is beautifully decorated with white and brass which creates a nice atmosphere and fun vibe. I have all of Yotum's cookbooks which are also fabulous. (There will be new releases soon!) The restaurant has a wide-ranging wine list and a fun cocktail menu. I had the "Saffron Chase" which comprised of Chase gin, champagne, elderflower liquor, and saffron...very refreshing. Dinner ("Sharing Plates") included Burrata, peach, coriander seeds, and plum wine; twice-cooked baby chicken, lemon myrtle salt, and chili sauce; beef sirloin, black garlic, salt baked avocado; and truffle polenta chips with Parmesan and garlic aioli. I selected the coffee and pecan financiers with maple cream from the "Pudding Menu" for dessert. Delicious vegetarian options are available.  ottolenghi.co.uk

photos.caption: Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom
Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom
Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom

7Y7ITKRFvHuUm3VKDltxRQ.text: I heard a lot about this chic restaurant that's slightly hidden from the busy high street of Regent Street and frantic shopping area. I booked a table for three at least a month in advance for a table on the top floor and got a table in the middle of the room. Me and my company went for a tapas feel of a dinner and ordered mainly different sides. The dishes that stood out from the many vegetarian sides were the Valdeon cheesecake and Pork belly dishes. We also got complimentary bread and olive oil but quite sparingly and had to ask for more during the course of dinner. I also asked if they had any other types of bread like they did in the Ottolenghi in Liverpool Street, with a mix of dark and light bread, but they sadly didn't. I was very impressed with the warm cheesecake made from Spanish cheese but since I don't eat meat never tried the pork. My company liked the pork dish but said it wasn't really anything out of the ordinary. All in all it is a lovely restaurant but I rather choose the Ottolenghi in Liverpool Street to be honest.

photos.caption: Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. The yummy warm cheesecake! Winner of the dinner in my book.
Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. The pork belly, butternut squash and Valdeon cheesecake in the background.

gAkfvOlmLhANarwORLR8Rw.text: The coolest part about NOPI? The bathroom. The service was great, but I wasn't blown away by the food.  My favorite dish was the twice cooked baby chicken.  We also tried the burrata with coriander seeds, truffled polenta fries (I've personally had better - if you're ever in San Francisco, check out Andalu), courgette fritters, and scallops (which were kind of cold).  Everything was good, but it wasn't exceptional.  I'm not sure if I'll return.

q307dPBvQUufwl1Cg_hYLg.text: Busy, trendy, pricey, good. Love this place. Keep up the good work

photos.caption: Photo of NOPI - London, United Kingdom. Spicy fish cooked in banana leaf

nAGGpSK16Rc75DtGQV_NHA.text: We got here at 10:20am, for a Sunday 10am breakfast reservation. On our way to the Ottolenghi restaurant, they had called us to confirm that we were still on to meet the reservation because we were running late. The service was superior; the food came out quickly, everything looked, felt, smelled and tasted impeccable.We started with the best tasting croissant in London. English breakfast liquor tea by the side.The bagel with Hansen & Lydersen smoked salmon on a bed of wasabi cream was adequately loaded with fish, fresh and bursting with flavour. My sister ordered the black rice porridge cooked with coconut milk topped with banana and mango (comes with extra coconut milk for added richness and palm sugar for sweetness), which was good too, but in my mind the extra coconut milk will need to be used to do it proper justice. I have a bit of a sweet tooth too, so some of that palm sugar won't hurt either. A little bit of extra fruit might have enhanced the taste of this fibrous porridge. My favourite, which is what I ordered, was the mushroom on sourdough, iced with a dollop of poached egg. The place looks of course, like an archetypal Ottolenghi establishment, bathed in white hue descended on the even whiter marble floors. I didn't feel the gold enough though (come on Yotam, give me some more of that aurous glitter!). The bathroom tiles bring out the white even more, and if it not were for the slight dullness outside, I would have had a little bit of a headache at the end of it all. I suppose that synthetically created solar emotion in a restaurant is not so bad for us, Vit D starved Britons.The bill, £50 for 3, sounded about right. I'll be back for dinner!

Nv-q3XlDsW8sPwl9eaZbhw.text: A nice atmosphere, service is good, I've tried it for lunches and breakfasts. The baby chicken is really tasteful, plus their cheese selection used in different dishes is good. My favorite at NOPI is their breakfast. I never went wrong with any dish, all different eggs were tasteful, and the French Toast as well.Book in advance since they will always try to seat you at "NOPI Downstairs" although it is not bad, but personally I prefer eating upstairs. Downstairs is a long table with a long bench that you will be sharing with everyone else setting next to each other facing the main kitchen. You could try it once! Overall, it has been always an enjoyable experience. Cheers

oq6Nkgc3eQH90qxfo4d2cA.text: This is a MUST GO stop for any foodie visiting London!! The food is absolutely delicious. There is always a large array of wonderfully innovative salads that will wow your taste buds with unthinkable combinations. Great place to stop for a bite to eat after a long day shopping or dinner with family and friends. Atmosphere is laid back yet proper. Also love their other restaurant in East London Ottolenghi.

bN5YcOZjKBFgUAnDTgZEgQ.text: By golly, this place is amazing!  My sister and I are both vegetarians and were told to come here by a friend specifically for their veggie options.  I loved everything!  The cheesecake (small plate, not dessert) was like a delicious blue cheesy bake that I wish I had the recipe for.  The potato cakes were our favorite.  The zucchini croquettes were good but only order this if cardamom makes top 5 favorite foods for you.  I love cardamom but it was way too much for me.  Cocktails are also tasty tasty!

XBLZjCw7qJPG_rD07qzOGg.text: Simply delicious and fantastic service! Started with several tapas. The twice cooked chicken was my favorite. Second favorite salted Carmel ice cream

Bai4LCD_ZKDg8Hd_NUITfg.text: Worst possible service for a restaurant with outstanding vegetarian offerings and inventive cocktails in a beautiful, simple space.I arrived, a woman alone, but with a confirmed reservation, at 5:30 PM, and after being ushered to a small table by the serving kitchen at the entrance was virtually ignored.As to the food and drink:The small plates are magnificent...when they arrive.The Woodford Old Fashioned with chocolate bitters and the fragrance of orange was startling at first and became something to sip soothingly during long waits.Order the sweet potato and the burrata with coriander dishes for certain.The coffee was lukewarm, but there was no hope of finding someone to heat it....and there was a long wait for the £42 bill.I'd try another of their restaurants, but NEVER GO BACK TO NOPI AS A WOMAN ALONE.

LR3cdbRHHrBF3K26WTco7A.text: The service is very patchy. We sat there for over 1/2 hour before any one asked us if we want a drink. Another 1/2 hour passed before we got a bottle of rosé which was warm. Took another huge effort to get attention to order appetizers and main. Service, service, service. By the time you get the food you are so annoyed at how slow the service was!

nNWZcepMFLSSx3oyi1tpkA.text: Everything was cooked very well and ingredients were high quality, but some flavour combinations missed the mark. I really wanted to like this, but unfortunately don't find myself wanting to go back.

hQ8W5G8Hq1iTwlajOKrkNw.text: Went here for dinner before the theatre. Excellent service and food. Recommend getting several dishes to share

ACwd0jULkvH6u4hH-YS6dA.text: Another fab meal at NOPI last week. Imagination and subtlety in the dishes seems to grow rather than get stale. So many other restaurants are disappointing when you return after an initial wow meal - but not this place!

-tzMZy_vA2vg0mHaa-NkOg.text: wow. what a great little place that features the wonderful food of Ottolenghi, one of the stars of middle eastern food in London with loads of places. We were eating downstairs, which is literally two big communal tables in the storage area of the open kitchen. you can watch the concentrated flow of the talented kitchen staff and enjoy lovely and high quality middle eastern dishes. We shared a couple of nice ones from the starter section (perfect for a communal table) and followed the advice of the nice couple sitting next to us and ordered the chicken, which was truly tasty. you have too book in advance.
